content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								Pit People is XCOM, Fire Emblem, and Pokemon thrown into the minds of Behemoth and what they made is a funny and good looking game. The meat of the game is doing battle with teams of bad guys with your very own squad that you find through the story mode until you find Sophia the Recruitador (a lot of characters in this game have funny names). Then, the game branches into another way of playing it. You can capture any unit you fight on the battlefield when you leave it as the last one alive. There are several character classes from the human fighters to the penguins to the beefy giants to the cupcake healer class. Every character has their own name from Gluten to Pipistrella.This is an early access title as of January, and it shows only in the story mode. The rest of the game is polished and balanced with each weapon type and class, but the story mode is farly short. What it lacks in length it makes up in character and gameplay. The narrator Stamper was present in their previous game Battleblock Theater as well but he takes the role of a godlike bear that overlooks the story as a sort of meta-narrator, talking to the characters and talking to the player. Apart from the short story quests, there are a few side quests that are all five parts incrasing in difficulty. These serve the same purpose as side quests in different games, to give you some more gold and flesh out the characters. These side quests take a bit longer than the story. Apart from the insanely fun singleplayer, there exists an in-universe multiplayer PvP called the Pit, which is pretty much the only reference to the title of the game. You and a partner control your squads to defeat two other people's squads. It's a very satisfying game mode as you can learn from the other people's squad composition to increase chances of success. Think XCOM PvP. You get story rewards as well depending on how many games you win per day. As it is now, Pit People is very fun and well balanced even though the story mode was short and as sweet as the cupcake healer class.

content:
Posted: January 13
Early Access Review
								I haven’t seen very many qualitative reviews yet, so I’m attempting my own. This is based on what I’ve experienced in the game so far playing three hours on my Xbox One and on Steam altogether.A turn-based strategy game, you can build a team of up to six characters with their own customized equipment. Everyone can have different weapons, some with effects and some that are strong against enemies wearing particular equipment. An example of this is that swords will be weak against people with helmets but maces will be strong against them. While customizing you character, you will see a bar graph which tells you their equip load, damage, range, defense, and dodge. Going above 100% equip load will reduce the character’s move points by one, and staying below 50% grants an additional move point. You can designate one person on your team as the hero. Doing so gives them more health, damage, and greater equip load.The combat is fairly simple. Move your melee team members adjacent to enemies, and they will attack them. Ranged team members supposedly need at least one empty space between the enemy and themselves. If there are multiple enemies that can be targeted within the vicinity, that unit will seemingly choose a random enemy to strike. Some of the fights can take a few minutes depending on how fast your thinking is when it comes to moving your team.Early in the game, you will find a city where you will be buying some of your items, fighting in the pit against A.I. or other people online for gold, and customizing your characters or changing your team members as you obtain equipment and people throughout the game. Gold and items can be obtained outside of this place, but you are limited to how many items you can carry. Two important items I’ve come across are campfires, which allow you to heal your team outside of combat, and recruit cages, which allows you to recruit enemies to join your team. Mind that you will need to unlock the recruit cages through meeting a certain character first. I would recommend not fighting in the pit early in the game against A.I.'s beyond story mode. Three consecutive rounds can be difficult to finish.Story mode is not finished yet, but there are many battles across the map you travel through outside of combat. Alongside the story mode quests, there are other quests you can choose from. You can also encounter optional quests while exploring the map. The game will point you to the objective once you’ve accepted a quest.The art and music are reminiscent of previous titles, but they feel updated as well. The narration is just as funny as it was in Battleblock Theater. Castle crasher players will recognize the combat style immediately. Battleblock Theater players will know how this game is loosely connected to it.I've recently tried co-op. Pretty much the second person you play with will have the same stuff as you from the very beginning. When you unlock a character, they get a variation of them as well. They will also have the main characters in character selection when they have the chance to change team members.I have not tried PvP yet, so I can’t say anything about them. Hopefully someone else can tell you guys about them. Other than that, that’s all I can tell you about the game. Hopefully you will find other qualitative reviews better than mines. If you buy the game, I hope you enjoy playing it as I did.

content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
See written review below or watch it here: 


YouTube™ Video: Pit People - Review (Early Access) 

			Views: 3,045		

			Pit People is a strategy adventure game with turn-based combat brought to you by the developers who also made BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers.		

TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION!Pit People is a strategy adventure game with turn-based combat brought to you by the developers who also made BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers. Pit People is a different genre of game than their previous games, but the character style and sense of humour is consistent in Pit People as well.You create a team to with up to 6 characters on it, and battle against the enemies in turn based combat until one team is defeated or your objective is accomplished. I’ve been playing mostly on normal difficulty. I always heal to full health before each encounter, and so far I haven’t found the fights too challenging. I tried a mission on the insane difficulty, and if it wasn’t for my characters leveling up (to restore them to full hp) mid-combat, I would have died for sure. You can bring more than one of the same character type at a time, but the cupcakes don’t heal other cupcakes. If all of your characters die, you lose some gold and maybe some items, but there is no perma-death, so the game is forgiving in that sense.During your turn you lock in all of your moves at once before ending the turn. If you make a mistake with the move, you can always change it before you end your turn. You are given plenty of time to lock in your moves. The combat has some random factors, like dodging, crits, and most notably which target you actually hit. You have control over your team’s movement, but you have no say as to which target you will actually attack. For example: if you place a character in a hex that’s adjacent to multiple targets, your character can attack any of the available targets, and not necessarily the target you want. There is friendly fire with AE abilities, and you can accidentally heal enemies as well. You journey out from town to explore, or complete missions by driving around the map in a nitro-boosted wagon...that poops. There are enemies everywhere, but it’s nice that you can easily avoid combat by stunning them and running past if you want to. It’s a lot better than having to flee combat, since fleeing makes all of your characters take damage, and drops your items on the ground. You can play by yourself against the AI, or in two player co-op either online or locally. There is voice and text chat In co-op, so you can coordinate easier. Both you and your ally take your turns at the same time, and there are a lot more enemies to compensate for there being a second player. There is also an arena where you can battle against other players in 2v2 battles or compete for scores on the leaderboard against AI.In almost every battle, you have the option to recruit the last remaining enemy by capturing them with a net and cage. I think it’s awesome that you can capture any enemy you come across, and that it never fails to capture. It’s also neat that you get to keep all of the equipment that they are wearing when you are recruit them. Sometimes I wish I could capture more than one enemy per battle though. There are different species that have special abilities, and other species that can be equipped with gear. There are no skill points to allocate, but the equipment let’s you customize each character.Pros:the same Behemoth style and humourlots of side quests to do, and some have their own mini stories to go with themTONS of collectible items to find - most are purely cosmetic, while others have various combat stats, and you can also trade items with other players (I played for about 10 hours, and only got 9% complete)the gameplay is fun, but can get repetitive after a while (I still got my money's worth)voice acting for the narrative (Will Stamper, from BattleBlock Theater) is amazing, and the goofy made-up language with voice acting is rather entertaining at timesmost of the sound effects are decent, and soundtrack is good, but it won’t appeal to everyone.good looking unique and colourful environments that are all designed with hexesawesome animations, and fantastic character customizationskeybindings are fully customizable, and there is full controller supportCons:the game lacks a full-sized map that shows all the areas you’ve explored - since you can only have 2 active quests at a time, it would be nice to have a large map marking points of interest you’ve seen, but not yet completednot much of the main story it available yet as expected in early access (but at least there are a lot of side quests available)(nitpick) the clouds everywhere blocking vision while driving around is annoying(nitpick) the randomness of which targets you actually hit can be a pain sometimes(nitpick) it can sometimes be hard to tell which hexes you can’t walk on(nitpick) when you are running through enemies avoiding combat the aggro sound is quite irritating (they should lower the radius that prompts the sound)Conclusion:If you’re hoping for story, there isn’t much in the way of a story campaign just yet, but there are still plenty of quests to do.  Playing against the AI as single player is fun, but it feels repetitive after a while. The co-op is enjoyable, but I wasn’t able to try the PvP since I got impatient waiting for it to pop. Overall, it’s a nicely polished turn-based strategy game that’s not too punishing, and it has an abundance of collectibles, and the sense of humour you would expect from a Behemoth title. I have no regrets with the purchase, and I look forward to more of the story being added.If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations here.You can also view this review on my website here.[www.azralynn.com]

Early Access Review
								First thing to note is that game being early access just means the story is not complete. Gameplay is finished, and there's a lot a of quests (which vary a lot) and stuff to do, including PvP mode, and extra difficulty. However, expect that after 2 hours, you'll have finished the story in it, which doesn't mean the game ends.I loved the presentation of the game. classic Behemoth style, with a lot of humor, the same hilarious narrator from Battleblock Theater, and a lot personality behind it. Great music, with a lot of variety. For me, one of the selling points.The gameplay is also great, however, is much simpler than your average turn based grid strategy game. Your characters attack on their own if they are on range of an enemy, for example. If you're looking for "hardcore gameplay", you might be disappointed with it. But I think that it goes in the right direction and if fits the game, while being very accesible for people not so into the genre. This is neat because the game has local and online co-op, so you can play this with a lot of people, not just hardcore turn based gamers.Overall, i really liked the game. I would recommend it if you like the presentation, and you want to be playing it just to explore the world that the Behemoth people hace created. If you're looking for a story driven campaign already finished, wait for the full release.

Couple that with the "recruit" (basically kidnap your team members into slavery) mechanic, the mind boggling amount of team combinations, 2 player, The Pit where you can PvE or PvP and the ludicrous amount of loot and this is a no brainer. I am trying not to burn out on the game as its in EA but I keep coming back for more,  there is already a staggering amount of content with more to come, highly recommended.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I'm happy to add another positive review to the thousands of already existing ones. Let me explain why.Pit People is a great game and yet another instant hit, like Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theater before it. It might seem like youtuber bait at first glance, with all the "memes" and (literaly) toilet humor, but it's got depth, it's got great customisation and it's got humor that is gonna appeal to all ages. The Behemoth team delivered again (might I mention, they are the only devs with multiple games that all have 95% on steam I know) and I'm looking forward to watching the game evolve and grow.Now let's get started for the actual review. As you might have already noticed, the aesthetic is very similiar to the previous games. The similarities don't end there either. You will often encounter creatures from the previous games and all kind of other references. These apear mostly in a huge variety of costumes and already mentioned creatures. So how is Pit People different? Well, almost everything else is new. The combat system is turn based, kind of simplistic but very well implemented. Each creature has its own (mostly passive) abilities and stats, which can further be modified by items and weapons. Latter stands mostly for humans. There are four different types of elemental damage (fire, explosion, poison and ice), but there are also helmets and shields, armor, dodge and many more mechanics, that make fighting interesting (hint - stay AWAY from the farting mushrooms).Your base of operation is a town where you pick quests, equip items, fight in a pit or simply buy new items and fighters (there is no need for that really, as you frequently get them during wandering anyway). Once you set foot on the huge map, you encounter various groups of enemies, which you can avoid or fight. You can also pick up new quests on the fly, ranging from quite a selection. I've heard there are more than 100 avaliable.Another big thing I've yet to mention - co-op. It's not 100% required in order to have fun, but it helps to have a partner. You both plan out your turn at the same time and due to much larger number of fighters, it can really get quite chaotic (which suits the theme of the game). However a thing that has been bothering is the camera, which is quite wonky during co-op battles, expecialy on larger maps. But hey, that's why early access exists. The last thing I'd like to cover is the look, sound and narration. I've already stated the cartoonish look suits the game perfectly and I stand by it. Naration is done by Will Stamper, same old cynical guy you've had to put up with in Battleblock Theater. He does a fantastic job in being both annoying and funny at the same time, pestering your heroes and making smug remarks. The soundtrack is great as well and I haven't gotten bored by it even after 10 hours of play. ConclusionWould I recommend Pit People? You bet your♥♥♥♥♥I would. It might not be 100% finished, expecialy the main story is lacking at the moment and I hope more creatures get introduced during development. Still, the game is well worth its price and has made me chuckle many times (expecialy some of the names). It's just as silly as it is serious and the combination simply works. BIg thumbs up from me!Rating: It's early access you silly, I can't give a rating.

Early Access Review
								* Do remember this is Early Access, and as such the value of this title as I review it.  My review is based mostly upon the mechanics and what is here, rather than a story that has yet to unfold.Behemoth once again delivers a class A experience with their one of a kind over the top humor. A robust and expansive world, a myriad of memorable characters, and enough loot to make your butt fall off.  Pit People has a diverse and simplistic combat style accessible to players new to the strategy RPG format. Yet still it goes so much deeper than that to the true strategist. Offering near limitless customization this game allows for any playstyle. From people who like to hide behind ponies, to those who crave the boom boom, to those who simply love rainbows. Whether you are a tried and true fan of Behemoth and their past works, or a newcomer to the party, I do believe this is shaping up to be one of the best games of the coming year. That being said, if you are looking strictly to play a large story filled with conquest, glory, and pain, Pit People may not be the title you want...YET. As it sits you will not run short of things to do, amongst them being PVP, Co-Op shenanigans, loot hunting, side quests, and dying with laughter. This is not a typical gotcha early access. What you get right now, without the story, is well beyond the price value. Behemoth made the right decision to let us get the jump start on such a sweet game.Pros:+ Excellent Voiceover+ Wonderful and Diverse Art+ A+++ Soundtrack+ Fluid and Simple Combat+ Deep Customization+ Fantastic Price Point+ Contains the Color Teal+ Fantastic and Lag Free PVP Servers+ Co-Op Couch Play (Bless you Behemoth for keeping the old ways alive.)+ Early Access (This game is well and far beyond what I expected to get at day 1 early access.)+ Flawless Controller PlayCons (Most Likely To Disappear by Full Release) :- Early Access (This is only a con because my body is ready for the whole thing.)- Difficulty Curve for The Unsuspecting/New Player (A.I.'s beyond story mode is a CHALLENGE, PVP garnishes more experienced SRPG Players)- Keyboard/Mouse Controls Need Refined- Can't Buy The Soundtrack

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
Pit People is great fun! A few things definately need to be worked on and tweaked, but hey - for an Early Access game from a well-trusted developer, this is looking real good.Essentially, this plays like a modernized quirky version of Final Fantasy Tactics. Everything you want from a tactical turn-based party battle management game is pretty much here. Lots of collectibles, both functional and cosmetic. Definately has a good chunk of different kinds of units (the deep customization really helps here in making it feel even more extensive). The online play is off to a great start - they are doing it right.One thing I'll say right up front is that I'm thoroughly confused about people complaining about the short 'main story line' right now. First off, that's the tutorial folks - there is more coming. Secondly, there are over 100 missions WITH storyline dialogue that will certainly take you over a dozen hours to complete. Thats a conservative estimate, too.You can read about all the good stuff in, well, like every other review. What are the negative points?First off, the camera desperately needs work with local co-op. They already said they would fix this as a high priority, so fine. Secondly, while the map is huge, it sort of, well, lacks a strong flavor. I think it feels very flat, and simply uniformly dotted with either small buildings or landscape chunks. While the map artwork is good and that is set, I'd like to see a bit of TLC go into making the terrain feel better in general. I hear keyboard and mouse controls are abismal, so be warned (I didn't try them because of this warning). Lastly, I think the music is fantastic, although it is not very artistically cohesive. One minute it is high fantasy classical-esque, then it's western cowboy music, and yet another it is techno-ish. Don't get me wrong, it is all very good, but sometimes this difference made me wonder about how it was all chosen and put together.Another thing I'd like to mention is the difficulty. In five hours, I had never lost. Mind you, I didn't play on 'insane' difficulty, but still. I finished the 'main story', which is just a tutorial or prequal to the actual story (this version ends where it appears the real story begins). I finished 11 quests and a few other things. After a while, I got lazy and stopped really strategizing and just kept throwing units in haphazardly - and I still won. With only a few hours in, I'm going to chalk this up to early game build-up. Plus, I think online play will likely be a different story. I did play online, but only very briefly.Lastly, I felt that single player mode felt much better than local co-op. Local co-op was fun, but the screen was almost too busy, and I felt there was even less strategy. It was like 'just send the units wherever they are next to an enemy' kind of thing. It worked, which is the questionable part.Pros:+Fantastically addictive combat; everything is done really really right+Although I didn't like Battle Block or Castle Crashers as much as everyone else (I felt they were shallow), this game has really hit the mark with the depth it brings, respectively+Controller support is great+Don't be fooled - there is a ton of content right now; yes the 'main story' (ie. tutorial) is less than 2 hours - I assure you this will change; further, there are over 100 side quests and some 1,300 collectibles right now (I could see 15-20 hours easy - as an estimate)+There are various parts of this game to enjoy, and it smartly lets you choose - you can turn on AI to actually do all the battling for you, which is great if you just like the larger aspects of the gameCons:-Difficulty is questionable - I can't seem to ever lose-Local co-op is just too busy to be enjoyable; it hardly felt strategic, either-While the music is great, there is no artistic cohesion; this may be fine, albeit weird-Overall, I'd like it to feel like there is more strategy involved than what I've felt so farI think this title is great, and definately worth full price.

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								I have nothing but respect for those at the Behemoth, one of the first indie studios out there, from alien hominid on ps2 to castle crashers to battleblock theater, the effort they put into their games stands out not just in quality but personality. The lineage for the company is one worth reading about, and If you're familiar with Newgrounds, you probably know the long history there,but these guys have been at their unique blend of game-spices since I was a wee lad, and it was a bootstraps effort to put the dream in motion and it wound them here on release of a hilarious fourth incarnation of a game only they can make and would be a pity to miss.  Unlike anything the Behemoth has done yet, the gameplay is layered, but easy to pick up, about as time consuming as you'd like it to be. The trailers speak for themselves, but the voicework from Stamper, the animation from Dan, the coding of a team that wrangles the madness together know what they are doing-if the early access tag has you 2spook'd. Cmon. It's the Behemoth, so for what I was anticipating, I was not at all let down. I say fifteen is a steal, and with all the art and animation and style and humor in here, you're not likely to find a game that has the kind of charm and wit with gameplay to match. Unique In short spurts or hours of competing for leaderboard rank, this hexa-brawly-turn-based strategy has more to offer than many out there of it's nature. As far as early access goes, this is tip top fare and well worth your $15.

Early Access Review
								If you're here reading my review you must be wondering if this game is worth buying or not. Well, I'll go ahead and let you sort out your own opinion and you can decide for yourself. PLEASE NOTE: This game is in Early Access, so don't let this review effect your views on the actual game when it comes out. Thanks!Pros:Great Team-Builder type game. If you love the type of game where it's critical to build your own team, this one is for you The units I've discovered thus far are as follows: Tank, short ranged but fast archers, long ranged but slow morters, healers, heavy hitter, DPS, and self-sufficient. All characters spare Healer and self-sufficent are interchangable. You may equip them with items varying from a rainbow.. bow to a chalk board with Einstine's "E=MC2". Though beware, as weight limits may prohibit you from reaching your characters full potential!In the world, you may fight to get loot. Beware though! If you lose a fight or flee you may lose your items! You must make the difficult decision of staying outside and battling for more loot as you complete quests, or you can venture back home and attempt to drop off your loot. Very good system!Wonderful balance. The game does a great job of making you feel challenged but not overwhelmed. Never before in this game have I desired to quit the game because a level was brutally unfair to me. It gives me a great challenge, even if playing with a friend, but if it gets too easy for you INSANE MODE is already implimented in the game and ready to use. Turning it on is as easy as completing the tutorial level.The game becomes self-aware.. mostly. The game only makes you complete its lengthy tutorial once, and after that you can jump right into your 5 out of 6 starting group and play away the day. It also holds nice polishes as to changes in the HUB city. Incuding little changes you might see after completing a quest.. The characters and personalitys are diverse. Going into this I was scared that all of the characters might be static and comedy-esq where I know they only joke. While yes this game has an AMAZING sense of humor, it is very careful to pick and choose when to be full on comedy and when to dawn the garb of light hearted seriousness.Many refrences. If you're a proud owner of BattleBlock or Castle Crashers like I am, you are rewarded with headwear for your characters that have.. actually pretty reasonable stats. Long live Hatty Hattington, The Tearful Warrior!Cons:The interface for equiping weapons and armor is... foreign to say the least. Things don't add up. There are three kinds of swords: Short, Medium, and Large (Forgive me if the names are wrong, but that's the jist). Good mechanic overall, but the swords vary in damage only slightly while other stats such as DODGE and DEF. may suffer or benefit greatly. I found myself unable to equip items that may have looked amazing, or that I got from the games Early Access finale. Worst of all is that the swords add to your weight, so I find myself using almost only the starting weapons since they have the most balance.Leveling is broken. A big part of the appeal to this game was the Leveling system.. only to find out it does nothing. Amidst the wilds of the map you might discover a wild band of raiders you wish to attack. You kill one and a beam of purple erupts from your character while the letters, "LVL UP!" appear briefly. Is it noticable? No, the ATK, DEF, Ect buff is so small you'd have to level up quite a few times. I'm talking 20+ times, and leveling up does get progressively harder.Armor eye appeal. There is said to be 1300+ items in the game to equip, and the majority look pretty cool. Be it a cup of joe to a Doge refrence. However... don't expect your people to look cool if you favor stats. As unbalanced as the items are currently, you are ALWAYS stuck with the default "T-shirt" so to speak. Cool helmet? Great. B.A. Sword? Even Better. I just hope those things look cool on your plain white shirt or furry black hair troll.Overall:This game is a wonderful game in my eyes, and I hate turn based combat spare Pokemon. It will take you on a few laughs and possibly make you wonder if Stamper's voice hurts after hearing his strange diologue where he occasionally yells. I feel this game is a wonderful addition to the Behemoth family and is on the forefront of breaking the bad trend of video game companies pumping out reskin sequels.For only the price of 15$ I would reccomend this game if it had a few more fixes onto it. It has a nice touch to it and great replay value to those who enjoy playing with team building options.What could be fixed/changed:Wagon upgrades, something to spend the money you'll accumulate as you progress. Something that's not needed nessesaraly, but something that would make the journey more enjoyable if you could customize your ride with cool looking cannons or an alternate horse type.Biome types. The game is very scattered and geographically makes utterly no sense. While yes, it is the Bear-apocalypse that doesn't mean the world should be as mixed as it is. I feel as if the map should have started with plains at least, expanding into a mountain zone to the west and a lake/island region to the east. Something to help pinpoint where the player is at. Something where the player could say: "To get to the Desert, go North onto the flaming fields, once you've reached the volcano zone stop and head east towards the island region. Follow along this route North-east until the islands begin to clump together and you'll see the desert. Enjoy!" Biome types. The characters are diverse in this game, but you take no advantage of it. Keep the little bandits in the fields, and the massive cyclopse men in the farther out areas so the player FEELs threatened. Am I saying exclude them from the lower levels? No, but I would suggest making them more frequent and powerful the farther they are from the current location of your Town is.Town/HUB Movement. It's a good idea, but if you went off of the Biome type idea I mentioned previously you might see an oppertinuty. This town movement instills adventure out of your comfort zone, but having the biome types could help the player navigate the landscape and perhaps even feel a bit more comfortable dodging the raining bear blood on their next quest.The Pit. Give the player the choice to "Descend" the pit. It would eliminate part of the feel of grinding enemies outside, but here's the twist. The pit only gives EXP and little gold. The real incentive is if you can make it to X floor then you get a reward. However, to make it a challenge for your team you have to get down to X floor in one go. Perhaps a checkpoint at every 5th, 20th, or 50th floor depending on difficulty of individual floors? This pit idea would make the overworld seem less comforting as you'd be spending less time there, and the game would seem bigger as there's another objective for the player to do.ADD TORSO EQUIPMENT. I've already said this in my review, but PLEASE add this. My team looks really sad-sack. I know the game is in the apocalypse, but the fact they never change shirts shouldn't hold in that situation either..Leveling. Perhaps if you got your character to say... LVL 100. There should be some kind of choice you can make. Here's what I think that choice should be. Getting to LVL 100 unlocks a quest where you BLAH BLAH BLAH you're left with the option to keep them at 100, split the 100 with the other team members on your team, or spend the levels on unlockables NOT NESSESARY TO THE GAME. Ex) Rare music disc's, unused Stamper audio, paints to re-color your items to make them match. Things a perfectionist, most people who reach 100 would be this, would crave.That's about it for now, as I'd hate to waste anyones time who's still reading this. I hope this review helped! Have a nice day!

content:
Posted: February 1
Early Access Review
								Pit people is a hilarious, turn based strategy game. It WILL have you laughing the whole damn time. What the game offers so far is a few hours of highly enjoyable gameplay co-op or solo. I would recommend getting a friend to play with though. As far as the "main" story goes I completed it in less than 2 hours and that was with some messing around and exploring. There are tons of side quests though and the Pit where you can do 2v2's or face the AI. You will gain daily rewards for winning in the Pit. The best part about Pit People is that it is genuinely funny and has the biggest♥♥♥♥♥♥of a narrator that I have ever had the pleasure of listening to. The narrator is a giant bear that tries to ruin your characters lives in the funniest, worst kind of ways. Every third or so time you return to your city, the bear will pick it up and move it somewhere else. Which isn't all bad because it keeps things fresh, but the nerve of some people, am I right? Just know that he will be intervening and "helping" you out in any way he can. PROSActual Humour"Easy To Learn Hard To Master Combat"Great TeambuilderCo-opTons of Loot and Cosmetics to CollectGreat SoundTrackCONSSort of Annoying Inventory Selection (I only used a mouse)Took Me Around 2ish Hours to Complete the Main Story Quests (EARLY ACCESS)RNG (not terrible xD)Overall Pit People definitely isn't a finished product hence the EARLY ACCESS, but there are still hours of fun to be had and plenty of laughs to well....laugh. If you are wanting a great game and are willing to wait a little while for more content then I would suggest picking it up. If you are into solo gamplay and want a story driven experience, I would probably wait until a few more patches or the full release some time this year.

Early Access Review
								I am someone who doesn't often purchase games.  However I played this to see what it was like yesterday with my girlfriend and we loved it so much I bought it.  It reminds me a little of Dokepon Kingdom on the wii.  I'm happy to purchase it and contribute towards its developement.   If you have a girlfriend that isn't so good with controllers or real-time games I recommend this to you.  I hope it has a lot of work and lots of improvement.  I still don't understand the leveling up or stats of each weapon (There are three types which are different) but I think the rest is just cosmetic.Edit 1 (Feb 11) :  Still extremely enjoying this game.  I understand now that the levelling up each time gives a toon 0.25% more stats.  Update two is also going to bring a lot of information regarding the weapons.  This game is awesome and I can't stop playing it with my girlfriend. It has got her into games so much I am out to buy a newer laptop so we can play more coop games like divinity etc.  Thanks behemoth! I will keep this girlfriend now!Edit 2 (March 29) : After the third update (Emperor's orders) I have to say this game is easily becoming one of my favourite games of all times.  I think I'll always remember it, kind of like, Borderlands 2 or WoW.  It has truly earned a place in my blackened heart.   We still play local coop and completely rip s*** up.  Mostly people are nice, but occasionally you'll find a bitter loser you'll tell you to suck some ****,  and you know, where else can you have a little cupcake wearing a robin hood hat tell you to suck his frosted candy pole?  It even uses his cute little voice while trying to portray his apocalyptic rage (since our tactics are flawless).  Edit 3 (April 13) :  Overall wait times to play 2v2 have increased a lot.  We wait 30-40 minutes for other players and they're usually the same 3-4 people we recognise.  Not sure what is happening.

Early Access Review
								Early access, so absolutely do not get it if you are expecting a full game with fleshed out story.That being said, I would still recommend this game to fans of Behemoth and people who like to play games in jolly co-operation. Gameplay is dynamic, though at the moment certain balancing could be (and should be happening) done. Units with high HP like the troll just steamrolls through even if pit against pixies. Support units like mascots and gnomes do not really have a felt impact, you'd rather bring something else of more worth than what is basically chip damage fodders. I have confidence that I can expect more from Behemoth, and do not regret my first ever early access purchase.Would like to add that the music choice is superb and very "Behemoth", reminiscent of their past games. TL:DR Get if Behemoth fan, wait for full version if hesitant.

content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
What could I say - I fall in Love. I feel unconditional, pure, raw Love for Pit PeopleThis game was on my radar since fellow named TotalBiscuit made a first impression video on it from PAX. Since then I was patiently waiting for time to come so I could play another game from The Behemoth - studio so different with their vision, with exciting and ridiculous sense of humor.Day of release has come, but I wasn't entirely sure to dip my toes into this fun loving, colourful water from get go, and I wanted to wait for full/finished product.Everything changed when I watched video by another fellow named Jesse Cox. Him and gentleman I already mentioned few sentences before, started series together. Watching them play, and having fun encourage me to jump right in without any hesitation.Oh boy! Oh boy! This game delivered.Five hours in so far and I'm having so much fun. Too much fun. Insane amount of fun; and what I say now, might be a stretch, but I feel Pit People is fun loving cousin of Darkest Dungeon and  XCOM in terms of excitement that I have in me while playing.Gameplay is just too damn addictive.Writing and humor so ridiculously charming. Possibilities with customisation are endless, same as number of different characters or creatures. Music is absolutely awesome, I can't wait for official soundtrack to come out.Visuals as always nice to look at, with many, many, many, many, many, many bits and pieces that makes the world feel vibrant and alive. Everything this shows how much though was put into this game, and you can see it from start thru multiple playthroughs.Besides unfinished story mode this game is polished to perfection ... well, I guess not perfection because inventory management bugs me quite a bit, more then I would like - but with this exception it is perfection in my eyes in terms of gaming experience.Well done oh mighty The Behemoth. You guys delivered another instant classic.I know, I know I'm just gushing no much saying praises, but it is just because I am filled with satisfaction and overwhelmed by how good this game actually is, and I need to get out of my system and spread it around. If you liked previous efforts from this devs, I don't know what are you waiting for; don't be like me and just do it! - BUY IT!Grade: A+

content:
Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								In Pit People you are a farmer and also a father who has lost his home and son. As you continue on, you dive deeper into insanity as you massacre entire populations of towns. You witness as innocent people are kidnapped in front of your eyes while you can't help them. You capture people to kill more efficiently. You let them die but bring them back to life to have them suffer the fate of death again and again. You kill people just for the hat they have on their heads. The story told is dark and chilling, showing us the struggles of Horatio in this unique setting. Pit People is possibly one of the greatest horror games of all time and will remain my favorite.

								Hi friends, This is the only game thats inspiried me to actually write a review.  If you enjoy games like Final Fantasy Tatics you'll love this game.  Although this is still early access the game is very much complete although some of the story is missing.  Not only is it hilarious but the game is very fullfilling to play.  The reason I've already played 24+ hours of this game is because of the pit.  The Pit is a place you can use the characters you've developed to fight other people in 1v1 or 2v2.  There are countless classes, weapons, armor and tatics on how you can win your next battle.After each battle if you keep 1 person alive you can capture him/her/it and it will join your team.  Any battle you encounter you can capture 1 of the enemies no matter how large they may be.  You then can use its armor/weapons to put on your other characters or keep them whole.  I'd easily pay $50 for the game as it is right now.  One of the best games i've played in a long time.  If your on the fence, buy it, you won't regret it.Much love and life!

content:
Posted: January 16
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								For a game that's early access, it really doesn't feel like it. I'm going to highlight what I feel is wrong/needs to be improved, in hopes the devs see it and consider it. For a review, I'll keep  it short. A very interesting world, full of LOTS of stuff, like LOTS, complete with music, great sound, and mostly good controls The music is amazing, I'll have it stuck in my head for days. Behemoth has yet another wonderful game out on the market. On to some gripes about the game.The PC controls are mostly good, but could use some fine tuning to make them not so wonky when selecting loadouts, the default controls are questionable, but rebindable so that's not that big of a deal. Also, in the intro, the load out screen and differences between "tiers" of items (i.e. cosmetics, light helmets, heavy helmets) isn't at all explained. It was super super confusing because I had no clue what I was doing. So the tutorial could use some more fine tuning as well. There are other things not very well explained, like what's on the HUD, I didn't know what I was looking at, or what it meant for a while. The items, such as campfires, and how to buy them isn't at all explained. I think my #1 glaring problem was the lack of explanation, so if you're reading this, Behemoth, it would be good to look into that.These are the most notable issues I saw, but damn this game is freaking fun. Doing Coop is sooooo much fun, but online is a mess. The biggest thing this game could benefit from is more flushed out tutorials, really explaining what everythng is. Keep it up Behemoth, it's a damn good game. Also, put people queued together on the same team. Or at least have an option to.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 98% YES / 02% NOGOODSome of my favorite visuals and animations. An incredibly cute and fun style.Combat is fun and frantic. You quickly internalize the best way to use the hex-based combat and how the AI targets units. There's a great amount of risk & reward, especially with the units with more powerful ranged attacks.Daily pit fights are a great way to test your teams out against "unfair AI" as the game lovingly describes them.An absolute silly amount cosmetic weapons & armor that make constantly refitting your crew a joy.Overworld is exciting to explore, especially since the space bear moves the town around every so often so you have new maps / areas of the maps to explore.Side quests galore! So many objectives to complete and even new ones to find in the overworlds. You're able to recruit so many units! Around 20 different species to unveil and collect. I've had a blast finding them and trying out their unique abilities. It makes building your 5 spot party intriguing as you wonder if you should have units that only take up 1 spot, 2 spots, poison immune, etc.The sound effects are incredibly pleasant and spot on. I'll also include the music in this section since it keeps me happy and smiling. They did great work on the soundtrack.Stamper's back to narrate from his Battleblock Theater debut and he nails it here as the evil space bear.The developer has stated they're 99% certain there won't be a wipe for data since most of the game is here. The side missions and combat are done, but they're still building the rest of the story missions.For $15 there's a lot of game in here. It's a great price.NEUTRALThe story missions start to drift away from the thrill that is the rest of the game, since I haven't touched the main characters for awhile and they've been out of my parties. Granted the story is still fun, albeit the portion that is being finished. I still love hearing the space bear ring chaos onto the land, but I'm barely invested in Horatio and Pipistrella's quest for revenge. SUMMARYAs an early access title, Pit People nail the fun, frantic nature of turn-based hex combat. Everything's an absolute delight down from the visuals to the soundtrack. I'm eagerly awaiting the full release but that won't stop me from enjoying it a great deal before then.

content:
Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								I was not expecting much from an early access game that's tile based, but this game took my low expectations and gave me one of the best strategic experiences I've had in a while. One reason you should think about getting this game for early access is because it's Behemoth, a trusted company who always delivers, so I don't expect this game to be in perma-early access. Unlike most tile based games you cannot choose your attacks and instead have to place your gladiators strategically to get them to do certain attacks. A mechanic I personally have never seen and enjoy. It makes the game insanely simple to learn, but mastering it a pain.  Not only are the mechanics good but the humor, artstyle, and sounds all make it feel like a well-rounded Behemoth game. Everything about it I enjoy, and best to get this game when it's cheap before the price raises because I know Behemoth won't disappoint. Once they're dedicated with a game they go the whole way through.

Early Access Review
								Absolutely fantastic game.Despite being in Early Access, all the key elements and ideas the game wants to use are there and they work very well together. This mad mix of Fire Emblem, XCOM and Pokemon works exceptionally well, and serves as a nice introduction to strategy/turn based games.The game comes with traditional Behemoth humor where anything can happen, and Stamper returning as the narrator makes for a very enjoyable experience!If it looks interesting to you, you'd be doing yourself a diservice to not try it now while it's in its cheaper Early Access build. You can learn and get a grip of the main mechanics for when the rest of the story mode is released in the full release, which is really the only thing that is missing.

content:

Early Access Review
								According to Steam I dumped 18 hours into the Closed Beta during the week+ it was going on. I haven't replayed the main quest yet to see the finished animations and whatnot, but just from the short amount of time I've run around the map in the Early Access version, I'm seeing the same fun game but with more. More quests, more loot, more customization, more ridiculously good time.Whereas the quirks of the Narrator and the occasional plotpoint rearing its head has put Battleblock Theater at the top of the list, for Pit People it is the sheer massiveness of the content combined with the replay value. I foresee this game being a favourite of a lot of people for the coming years, myself included. There's just so much to do and discover, and no chance of it tapping out any time soon.Highly recc getting this game, even in Early Access. It's a complete game, you just have to wait for the rest of the main quest to unlock. That's not so bad, right? In the meantime, there's a multi-tiered quest in Tinkletown waiting for your assistance.

content:
Posted: February 16
Early Access Review
								Pit People isn't even completed yet, and it fills me with all kinds of happy!  And blueberries.  I normally avoid Early Access and just wait for a finished product where I can plainly see if it's reliable and entertaining or not, but I have a lot of confidence in The Behemoth, and watching TotalBiscuit & Jesse Cox's co-op playthrough footage convinced me that the game is indeed in a good enough state for Early Access.  It is absolutely my kind of humor, especially with Stamper's quality narration, but I am also adoring the game on a mechanical level.  It's simple enough to where you're not bogged down with tons of tedious information, but still challenging enough to where you need to be aware of positioning and planning (before and during battle), or a Pixie may just burn off the faces of your entire team.Conducting battles is mentally stimulating, WINNING battles is often deeply satisfying, and the humor is the sweet, delicious frosting on the cupcake that just makes it that much better in the end!  I can't imagine a world without The Bear....

content:
Posted: February 13
Early Access Review
								Lets just start with pros. It's funny. And it's pokemon of sorts. It also is a tactical turn-based game, where you need to position your squad well, or face the consequences.Lets get to cons. It should be a game. But as of now, this is just a humor collection (and not the finest one either, let's be honest). This "game" horribly lacks one thing, and one thing only: GAMEPLAY. If you pick a character "A" and a character "B" of the same race, the only difference it will have is their level (and i actually doubt that it even has any significance). You can wear same gear as your other character, so what's the point? And most of the gear has no difference exept the looks. You wanna crush your enemies with golden scepter? Sure. You wanna do it with a lolipop instead? Fine, it matters not. You can even pick the giant ice-cream cone and it will be still as good for crushing your enemies, as the sax or some actual mace (this is somewhat untrue, since really rarely you get the gear with additional effects, like fire resistance, poinsoned attacks and stuff. But still). My biggest porblem as of now is that on the Xth battle you get bored. You probably have same characters as you had X-1 battles before, so you just do the very same thing you did for X-1 battles before, and kill your enemies the very same way you killed them for X-1 battles before. WHY? I had 30 level ups already, can't i be somewhat stronger? Can't i have some new skills to test? The best way to describe this game would be "like heroes of might and magic, but without heroes, and all you have is your army - which is forever limited to N units per squad". But if, one day, having 2 cupcakes will mean more than x2 healing. If, one day, having hummie "A" will mean something different from having hummie "B". If, one day, Horatio will actually DIE. That day will be the day when this game becomes much better than it is now.TBH, i cant say that this game is bad, or good. It is neutral. If you want some funnies, you will find this game better than neutral; If you want to play a game, you will find this game worse than neutral. But i will press the "not recommended" button, just for the sake of keeping balance with all those "recommended" reviews this game already has. Besides, this is Early Access. The game still has more room for improvement. So lets hope for the best, and watch events unfold.

Early Access Review
								This game is amazing, coming out of its shell from Newgrounds, The Behemoth has out done them selves with creating a game with more ear tingling voice acting from Will Stamper as every different race ever and a giant bear, but with also that iconic The Behemoth art style from Dan Paladin. And provides a new "Chess-like" turn based fighting system that also breaks out of there "Hack and slash" fighting style they had for Alien Hominid and Castle Crashers, while also completly move away from the side scrollers such as from the previously mentioned and Battle Block Theater. While also introducing even more of a variety of weapons then Castle Crashers, but allows the use of different effects from different armor, swords, sheilds, and characters. Not to mention the stunning crude humor it gives with straight out toilet/feces gags, to sarcastic, whimsical, and  just plain funny word play. At the moment i have come to the point of the game where things are starting to become dry in the free roam world (Which by the way, it has a free roam world) for i have beaten all the major quests, and sign up-able quests, and im starting to run out of run along quests that you find on your own, but while you wait for those updates to come rolling in, you can spend your time PvP-ing in the pit gaining wonderful spoils and gold, enjoy!

number of helpful: 35 of 66 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								I bought this game based on the fact that it had an incredible 97% positive score from over 2300 reviews and Stamper voice acting. For the first hour or so I was very entertained by Stamper, but I noticed the combat felt extremely simplistic. By the last couple of hours I played it for I was half-convinced I was just not understanding the greatness that clearly must be there based on the reviews. After reading the negative reviews I think maybe I'm not crazy and the gameplay in general is very shallow.I get that some people probably really like the collectathon aspect of the game where you capture all these different creatures, but when it comes right down to it all you're really doing is moving characters to appropriate hexes and ending your turn while hoping they crit with their one attack which you don't even get to decide who it's used on in many cases. Even the gear you equip your characters with has no real effect besides a few preset options like sword with shield or sword with bigger shield. The sword might be a candy cane or a golf club and the shield might be a cake or a playing card, but that has absolutely no effect other than cosmetic customization.It seems like a lot of people are very loyal to Behemoth and I get that maybe they're also investing in the potential greatness of the game down the road, but as it stands this game is absolutely not one of the Best games on Steam in my opinion like the ratings would have you believe. I hardly ever review anything unless I think the reviews are very skewed in a way I don't agree with and this is one of those cases. I do not at all believe this game is worth $15 in its current state, but I understand why some people might buy it in good faith that it will be in the future and then some. To anyone else reading this please do more research on this game rather than relying on the review system if that $15 matters to you.

content:

Early Access Review
								Game is awesome! The story and humor are what you would expect from a The Behemoth game (only played Battleblock, not Castle Crashers). Game play is relatively simplistic on the surface but there's a lot of potential for thought and optimisation during play and I assume especially for PvP.I likened the game to friends as Final Fantasy Tactics mashed with Pokemon with the art and humor of Battleblock.Worth a try even during early access as the game is very polished. If you can appreciate The Behemoth storytelling, this is for you, and if you like the idea of turn-based strategy games, this will be right up your alley as well.Also, the music is just great and so fitting in the game. If that's something that you like in a game, then the music just adds another reason to give it a go!

content:
Posted: January 21
Early Access Review
								To see the game in action and our thoughts, check out Catalysts Gaming’s Let’s Play:


YouTube™ Video: Let's Play Pit People Co-Op (Early Access) Pt. 1 - Tales of Blueberries 

			Views: 2,212		

			Pit People, the next game from the developers of Castle Crashers and BattleBlock Theater, has hit Early Access on Steam, and Jacob and Murphy are here to try out this new wacky tale of bears,...		

As a turn-based adventure game, Pit People greatly differs from The Behemoth’s beat-em ups Alien Hominid and Castle Crashers and puzzle platformer BattleBlock Theater. As with these games, though, the patented wacky Behemoth humor is definitely present and possibly at its best, with silliness around every corner, craziness that will leave you confused yet smiling like an idiot, and references to past games hidden (or not so much) in every nook and cranny. Stamper as the voice of an omnipresent narrator is particularly on cue with his side-splitting spiteful commentary and nefarious interactions with the game characters and world that can happen at seemingly unexpected moments as he looks to kill his boredom at your expense.For being in Early Access, the game looks and plays great, with solid controls and crisp, styled 2D sprites, though some of the UI could perhaps be cleaned up a bit or better explained. Your house in town where you can change out your team initially felt a bit overwhelming, requiring a lot of clicks to change out equipment and lack of button cues leading to a team member almost getting sold. Likewise, we received no warning that a quest would receive an F for Failure by returning back to town before we completed it, leading to an awkward visit with the local principal. Battles, meanwhile, could begin to get cluttered and claustrophobic, especially with the extra bodies and input in co-op, with allies and enemies having similar color and designs bunched up together on screen at once; there was often confusion on which character was currently selected and who was moving where. Our gripes are minor compared to the refined edges, though, and once you get things down, battles can feel intuitive while still retaining strategic complexity, allowing fights to be as fast-paced or as slow and methodical as you wish them to be. With a discount while in Early Access, Pit People appears to be another great game by The Behemoth that is worth a pick up and play, and we are excited to see the rest of the crazy content and wacky adventure that will be in the finished game.Catalyst Players/Reviewers: Jacob and MurphyVersion: Early Access - Jan. 18, 2017Played: Co-Op Campaign (3hrs)

content:
Posted: January 18
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun and simple game, yet it's deep and complex in a unique way.The story is comedical and light hearted which we've come to expect from Behemoth. The dialogues between characters are very humorous and unexpected. Although the story is very short as of now (the game only being in Alpha) the immense amount of side quests and the arena for PvP already gives this game long playability.The combat system is very well implemented, having different characters which are effective against others gives for a very diverse team builder. There is no one way to build your team and it is fun to test out different combinations and see what works.The character customization is a very fun aspect of the game, allowing you to collect, trade and create a very unique looking team. Since most (not all) of the changes in the same catagory affect only the look and not the damage you have no punishment in making your team look as crazy, funny or badass as you want. And I guess i should mention the NPC names... They're amazing. Enough said.Overall, I've been playing this game with a friend throughout, and I can say it is a lot of fun. We are excited for the whole game to come out but are right now content with finishing the many side missions and trying to beat the unfair arena (which by the way, is VERY unfair). I would strongly recommend this game to anyone. It's light hearted, funny and addicting; it's nice to see a game in Alpha that shows so much promise. I'd even go as far to say that if this was the final form of the game I would still spend the money on it.Now if you'll excuse me, I have a unicorn mortar team to make.

								This game! Oh boy!Behemoth has done it again, this time they hit what could quite possibly be one of their most engrossing ands fluid experiences. I've owned and played all of their games (excluding Alien Hominid) and have to say, this is easily tied for my favorite of their games.Strategic, fast-paced fun, that's all there is to it. While it's nothing major, it does severely effect the flow of the game for TRPG veterans, or people who understand how the turn will play out. Since movement is fairly.. Slow, due to low movement ranges and large maps, this makes a very tedious experience during overworld encounters, and while most will be fine with it, it'd definitely be a welcome change.

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								Pit People is a game that's basically a mix of a little bit of chess, a little bit of Pokemon, and some questionable humor. Overall, it's pretty good, but it doesn't really excel compared to its competition.PROS:- Very solid turn-based combat system.- Good jokes here and there.- 18 different customizable fighters, some more so than others.- Better art than Battleblock Theater and Castle Crashers, though it's still stuck in the cesspool that is the Newgrounds flash animation style.- Lots and lots of collectable items to equip your team with.- 6 team slots allows for a lot of customization and experimenting.- World is visually and conceptually interesting.CONS:- A bit too many jokes are only funny to people who haven't hit puberty yet, see: 


Here at The Behemoth, we come up with the most clever jokes imaginable to all of mankind. 
A Screenshot of Pit People
By: PlatinumJesus




- The soundtrack is pretty iffy. Some times it's good, other times it's like "what am I even listening to?"- If there's more than one target that your character can hit, you can't choose who you're going to hit. This can be extremely irritating in scenarios where you can either hit someone who's weak to your attacks or someone who's strong to it.- Aforementioned Newgrounds artstyle. It's alright, but comes off as a little... unprofessional?In short, Pit People is worth your time if you're looking for a creative, albeit somewhat generic turn-based combat game. I give it a 7/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								Pit People is honestly the one game I have played the most of in the last week or so - even though it's pretty obviously ment to be a more casual title.I won't try to explain to you why I did this, instead, let me just tell you about the things you can expect within this title that may lead you to become the same irrational human being I am as of now:- It's full of great, over the top humour. If names like Stamper and Psychicpebbles ring a bell, it's in the same vein as their stuff.- The combat is extremely simple with very little decision making. You don't decide what abillity a character is going to do and you do not decide which enemy he is going to attack. All you decide is where he will move. The Game will highlight his possible targets at the position you're moving him. He'll attack which ever one he feels like upon arrival. If there is only one target, of course, he will attack that one.- Another thing that adds to the combat is the variety of humanoids and monsters you can catch and add to your troops, with every race having different perks, passives and attacks. They all come with random names as well (which you will be able to see BEFORE catching them, so don't worry if you only want serious names.) Because, let me tell you, there are some real hitters in there. As of me wiriting this review, there are a total of 18 Races, not counting the different weapons some of them can use, which essentially makes them different units again.- The Main-Cast of characters is charming as all hell. Sadly, the main-story is not, currently,  very long - however that's going to be expected of an early-access title.- Staying with the theme of early-acces: This is one of the few games that actually seems to use that term rightfully. It's very much playable and you can already sink a good amount of hours into it, however, it's still, noticeably, not done. Don't worry though, the devs said previously that you are going to keep all units, items and general progress during the developement of Pit People.- Did I say Items? Yeah, for some people this is the biggest factor: You can find an insane amount of items in this game for every race that change their looks, sometimes drastically so. The same goes for weapons. Very rarely do these items have a bonus effect (the likes of: does fire damage, but less physical, etc.) - Also, there is meme-gear. I'm sure our creators look upon us in pure hatred and disgust at this point. So why not enjoy the ride until the inevitable heat-death of the universe.

content:
Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								There's a giant bear form space that crashes into the planet, where a farmer with a dead kid and a princess with daddy issues go after a band of gladiators on a shuttle, meet a hardcore Demi-clops, a cupcake (named Gluten), who heals you (with its' own frosting), and a strange Spanish lady with a fetish for netting people, help a guy poop in a town shaped like a giant toilet where pooping is banned, take part in the revolutionary war against the damned R3D C04T robots, save a burning town from the dreaded Fire Men so that it can keep on burning, find an orphaned baby leopard and return it to Dave, the Leopard Master, who doesn't like leopards, and generally enjoy a wondrous romp around a weird world full of nonsensical creatures and characters.Made by The Behemoth. Yes, THE Behemoth, not just a Behemoth... THE!!! Behemoth, capital E! From the same guys that brought you the co-op, cat-ertainment and spectacle-puzzle platformer BattleBlock Theatre and ridiculous side-scrolling adventures of CastleCrashers, comes Pit People, a "baby's first tactical game" with enough character and humour to finally fill that empty void inside!But what do I mean by "baby's first tactical game"? Well, Pit People is a tactical arena fighter wherein you have several pawns with different abilities, strengths and weaknesses, which you move around on a hex grid in a turn-based fashion. Think XCOM.But unlike XCOM you don't really have absolute control over your pawns. You can't really tell them what to do, only move them around (hopefully) "strategically". This makes the game somewhat more straightforward and easier than your average, XCOM-like turn-based tactical game. It does however present some difficulties XCOM veterans won't be used to.For one, since you can't tell your pawns what ability to use or which target to attack, you're pretty much left to the mercy of whatever Nuffle-worshiping algorithm decides that. More on that later however.In general, the game is pretty easy to grasp, the RPG aspects are limited to mainly just customisation options. While there is a ton of crazy loot, there's no plethora of uniquely different items with different stats- a tall shield is a tall shield, whether a garden fence or a giant beetle. However, within each item category there's the odd "special item" that sacrifices some of the normal stats of that category for a particular bonus. Want a shield with some fire resistance? Well, that comes with less blocking power, though not enough to make too much of a difference.Different character types (Cupcake, Cyclops, Demi-Clops, Human, Pixie etc.) have different proficiencies and characteristics, making them more or less potent with different items and loadouts and in different roles.There's no skill tree or talents (currently, as of Update 1, though that may also be planned), so every level your pawns gain is just a straightforward increase to all their stats, though not a major one. So there's no need to worry whether a 3% crit chance is better than a 1.5% increase to rate of fire. A level 10 character will always be objectively better than a level 9 one from the same type. In fact, the game (again, currently, Update 1 did make some stats clearer) makes very little effort to let you know what the exact stats of your pawns are. There's a bunch of nicely stylised bars - LBS (how much equipment a pawn can carry, since, as you can imagine, a tall shield is heavier than a buckler, which affects their movement and agility), DMG (how much total, maximum damage a pawn does, based on pawn type and equipment), RNG (range, for ranged pawns or ranged abilities like cage-throwing, each level on the bar represents a hex), DEF (defence against melee attacks, usually determined by helmets), BLK (ability to block arrows and other projectiles, usually determined by shields) and DODG (dodge chance, the lighter the equipment a pawn carries, the higher their dodge chance, based on pawn type), that give you some information on how powerful a pawn in a particular loadout is, though, save from the damage value, it's not particularly clear.There's also a range of icons for the different abilities and resistances pawns can inherit based on their type and equipment, though those provide little identification for what they actually stand for (since Update 1, the percentage chance of a particular ability to take effect is displayed below the relative icon, though that doesn't help much). Unfortunately, there's really no indication of a pawn's weaknesses, except maybe a vague footnote in your Recruitment Book (written and kept by the aforementioned Spanish lady).This may be a deal breaker for min-maxing nuts who care only for the most optimal approach to things, but in the spirit of this game, it's a well implemented system that takes little effort to get used to and navigate. Also, if you're one of those nuts, get out of here! This is a casual game, go back to your XCOMs! It also works well with the games' combat mechanics, or really lack thereof. Combat is determined on a rock-paper-scissors basis. A helmet blocks a sword but a mallet trumps a helmet. The UI is quite clear in this regard - if your pawn has an advantage against an enemy, there's a Facebookish "thumbs up" over that target, if it's weak or less effective, it's a "thumbs down".Attacks and order of operations is somewhat weird however. As I said above, the action and target a pawn picks is pretty much random. To a point. You can, and in fact have to, in order to make the most of every encounter, position your pawns in such ways so as to "guide" their algorithm.For instance, if there's two or more targets your pawn can reach, it will most likely spread its' attacks between all of them (or several of them, depending on how many attacks the pawn can make). If it has an advantage against one of them, it may favour that target with more attacks, or it may not. Moving your pawn to a hex where it makes contact with only one target makes it attack only that target however, giving it all its' got.Ranged combat is somewhat trickier however. Pawns with ranged weapons will always attack all enemies within their range for as many attacks they can make. They also attack in melee however and in fact prefer melee if they're "threatened" (have an adjacent enemy). They also usually have a "dead zone", a range of hexes below which they won't be able to fire at range.All of this makes combat both straightforward and engaging. Yes, all you're doing is moving chess pieces around, but much like actual chess pieces, your pawns have certain rules they follow when attacking/performing actions and you need to think about their order of operations and placement. Movement time is something you also need to consider as pawns that don't move/finish their movement first will attack/do their action while those still moving are still... moving, making for some unexpected results of potential targets getting flung out of reach of that perfect surround you had planned, just because that Hair Troll attacked first. And you can't simply overwhelm your enemies with numbers and brute power. Sure, larger pawns are more powerful, but they also usually take up an extra space on your team, so there's also that to consider. It is in fact you who would most often be outnumbered, since you'll often be engaging groups with more enemies than your team (even in co-op, the game adjusts accordingly).There's also no permanent death in this game, unlike other games of the kind, like XCOM, Darkest Dungeon etc. When a pawn dies in combat, it remains unavailable in your team until you return to town, after which it's as good as new! (scars and PTSD notwithstanding) As for the world and story... Oh boy, are you in for one wicked whirl!(Continue reading in the comments, this is a long one)

content:
Posted: February 28
Early Access Review
								Pit People is an adventure/turn-based strategy combo with an emphasis on humorous storyline, excellent cartoon artwork and the epic voice of Will Stamper.GameplayYou have a home village on a world map - it occasionally gets moved around by a giant purple six-legged teddy bear, but that's another story. You prepare your team of 6 fighters (selected from a growing pool of available fighters) with weapons and armour, then venture out in search of enemies to battle. You can either just go out and battle random enemies (they are all over the place) or else follow the quests. When you defeat an enemy, instead of wiping out all the fighters, you can capture the last one with a cage and recruit him into your squad. After a victorious battle you have to make it back to the village where all your loot is redeemed. If you're intercepted by another enemy on the journey back you risk having to battle them and lose your loot from the first encounter, but if you pay attention you can avoid this by using the cannons on the wagon to stun the enemies and slip past them, or use nitro to mow them down!The battles are turn-based, played out on a hex board. The way I've played there's not really much thinking involved and it's quite fast-paced. You move each fighter into position one by one then hit the spacebar to proceed, and they each make their own decisions about which enemies to hit. As they inflict damage and defeat enemy fighters they gain XP, making them stronger for future battles. The different weapons/armour you give them also make a difference to the team dynamics, if you want to get down to the nitty gritty. My 4 melee, 1 ranged and one healer has served me well so far.Inside the village you can buy new equipment in the market with the gold you've made on your excursions and play around with squad customisation, replacing members and switching equipment around. You can fight the AI in the Pit (within the home village) to gain some quick XP and gold, although I haven't had much success in there, I think I need to improve my team strength a bit more. You can use the big phone to dial up a PvP battle - I haven't managed to get a match yet but I haven't been too patient. This is a popular game so in general I don't anticipate any problems finding matches should I want to get involved with that later. At the moment I have more than enough to keep me busy with the singleplayer campaign.The quests (which you can pick up in the village) advance the storyline as you defeat and rescue various characters along the way. The cutscenes are a highly anticipated treat.Controller is supported but mouse is better.ArtworkWhen you look closely at the cartoony graphics you realise there's a great deal of detail here. Everywhere you go, the screen is packed with a seemingly endless array of funny looking enemies, absurd weapons and fabulous cutscenes. You never know what delightful thing you're going to discover next and it keeps you motivated to continue.SoundThe first thing I want to talk about is the theme tune. In my reviews I always comment on the quality of the music, but I'm always judging it as game-music, I would never dream of adding it to my actual music collection. Here is the first exception I've ever encountered. It's an awesome, rocking beat that belongs in the real music charts. The down side is that I have trouble starting the game. I sit at the main menu with my mouse hovering over the start icon, my neck jerking like a strutting pigeon. When I finally manage to tear myself away from that tune and log in to the game there are more great tunes to enjoy - selectable on the gramophone in the village - it's all very original, memorable and suits the game down to a tee.Will Stamper's voice acting has reached legendary status in the game world, his narration alone is worth the price of admission. There is no other voice like it. The absurd silliness and the way he yells "shut up!" is something I could listen to all day long. There is a lot of his voice in the game, but there is also a lot of content so naturally it's rather spread out, in the cutscenes and the odd impatient comment during battles telling you to get a move on. For me it's the main highlight of the game.DifficultyOn normal setting the singleplayer campaign and quests are fairly easy. I've won nearly all battles by just pushing my melee fighters towards the enemy and keeping my ranged and healer further away. In the home village there's an 'insane difficulty' switch that I dare not touch. I assume that you'd need to pay far more attention to the strengths and weaknesses of your team and your weapons in that mode.The Pit is difficult even on normal setting - you have to win 2 out of 3. I can usually win the first round but my team's health stays depleted for the next battle and I always lose. Perhaps I'll have better luck later on when my team has levelled up more.In conclusion, for me the enjoyment of the game is in the content so I'm glad that the battling is nice and easy and allows me to progress and discover it all without any hold-ups or frustration.PerformanceThe game is in Early Access but if you weren't aware of that fact you would never guess. There is still more content to come for the single player campaign, that's why it's in EA, but it already feels like a full game. Totally bug-free as far as I can tell, tons of content and it just generally feels finished and polished.Windows only, but there is a firm promise of Mac/Linux on release.ValueAfter 10 hours of gameplay I've barely scratched the surface. My overall progress bar currently sits at 10% so that should give you an idea of the amount of content here, not to mention online PvP multiplayer battling. It's not only the amount of content that's impressive, but the general quality of every aspect of it. The price right now is a steal and you should grab it right away - there will be a price increase after final release.SteamAchievements, cloud support, local/online co-op, local/online multiplayer. No trading cards but in this case it really doesn't matter. If you're going to let that influence your decision to buy then you're crazy.VerdictThe battling gameplay isn't exactly ground breaking or unique but it's very well implemented and satisfying. Everything else about the game - storyline, humour, voice acting, music, artwork, animation is absolutely outstanding. If you don't normally go for turn-based strategy, this is still a game you will love just for the bonkers fun of it all.The Behemoth: "We Make Games". Yes, they most certainly do.
