content:
Posted: January 17
Early Access Review
								I don't know much about Pit People, but I do know the plot for JoJo's Bizarre Adventure!In 1999 in the town of Morioh located in S-City, Josuke Higashikata is a popular boy in high school who becomes quick friends with one of his classmates, Koichi Hirose. When Josuke's nephew Jotaro Kujo (who's older than he is due to his father being his nephew's grandfather, hence the age difference) appears, Josuke is suddenly pulled into the world of the supernatural powers known as stands. One of DIO's henchmen has brought the Bow and Arrow to Morioh and someone has been using it on various people in the town creating Stand users—as discovered when one of them, the murderer Anjuro "Angelo" Katagiri, uses the power of his Stand Aqua Necklace to try and kill Josuke for interfering with his plans to rob a store and generally disturb the peace in Morioh earlier. Aqua Necklace manages to kill Josuke's grandfather, Ryohei Higashikata, in revenge for him being jailed by him. Josuke and Jotaro eventually capture him and, as a consequence of insulting Josuke's hair, ends up getting fused to the rock he was leaning on at the time, becoming a tourist attraction known as "Angelo Rock" in the process.

								So, far this is my favorite game of 2017. Behemoth has delivered with a fun comedic, and unique spin on strategy games. The story as of right now is short but, sweet. Combat is creative, and inuitive. Charcters are unique, and costemizable. I remember feeling the way I did when I got Civ V. The Behemoth has really pulled through on that One More Turn ordeal. Even though this is in early access this is a must buy for any Behemoth fan, and a must buy for any strategy fan. As if Posiedon himself put his hand out in friendship ,and they spat in his mouth!

content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								Okay so, let me say I don't hate this game. I've actually been looking forward to it since it was annouced, as I am a huge fan of everything Behemoth does along with one of my favorite actors/voice actors/people Stamper. However, this game really just isn't fun to me. Like, the combat itself is extremely weak and unsatisfying as nothing really feels like you're actually doing anything. You can't plan for any battle, you can't choose who you attack, weapons are often just reskins and stats don't really matter too much. I know no one really cares about my opinion, so I'll just be brief. I find it hilarious, like the portion that is done was really funny as Stamper always is. The humor is here as they are known to do, but gameplay wise it's the weakest game yet. I'm really hoping somehow they fix it since nothing really feels fun besides hearing Stamper make silly voices.

Anywho, he embarks upon an epic quest to own his own private zoo, sanctioned by the great emperor Hulius Iceberg II himself. content:
Posted: March 23
Early Access Review
								Soundtrack is AWESOME, as is narrator writing BUT gameplay and long term progression too vague and too random As a tactical "rpg-lite" the gameplay is ok, based on your group composition you subjugate and loot new team members and items to give you more options for more team compositions. As early access the story line is unfinished but the writing and 4th window breaking is funny. However there is little progression, and even early on i see a grinding mechanism which is completely random and arbitrary. As you play the game your characters supposedly level up but they do not become visibly stronger as numbers are not defined , the levels on the individual characters seem completely random and no measure for tactical planning is allowed for the player, for example my level 4 characters caught a level 25 mob. Did it suddenly mean all the random encounters scaled up? Did it not matter? who knows as no info is given. Random encounters are completely random as well, You have no idea of the difficulty or composition of the random encounters. my low level team was near wiped out when i first met pixies doing AOE fire damage and i had no clue the pixie was there as i could not click on the encounter to get a clue . all in all at this point i cannot recommend this game as RPG or a adventure rpg or a tactical game unless you are completely into PVP. Which i did not indulge as the frustrating randomness of single player mode was too annoying

content:
Posted: February 8
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								I wanted this game to be good, but there are a few very important things that makes it disappointing. You get a team, and it's a turn by turn game where you get your team to fight other teams. The only thing you can control during combat is the movement of your characters. This is important because you can't control who your characters attack. Everything is extremely tanky, therefore no strategic planning is involved. Also, there are over 1000 items but 99% of them are cosmetic. What this means is that there are basically no strategy involved in what items your characters should equip. Yes, there are some very minor strategic decisions but they won't yield any interesting gameplay.

number of helpful: 16 of 46 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
Early Access Review
								I'm reviewing this game in it's current state, and so far, I've had alot of fun with Pit People. The humor is perfect, and the art is fantastic. There are so many different weapons and units to delve into and figure out; However, this is part of the problem. The game throws you in with a minimal tutorial and trying to figure out the game can be quite overwhelming.My first complaint is the way the team customization menu is set up. When trying to choose new swords or helmets for my characters, I often feel its very clunky and uninformative, and the lack of individual statistics for each piece of equipment, trying to figure out the balance of the game is hell. There is also no point in really equiping a sword over a mace because mace's can bash helmets. Swords cant and they both deal around the same damage.My second complaint is the different races and what they're good against and weak against. It simply gives symbols without telling me what exactly those symbols mean. I wish there was more direction in what these mean and more explanation in the Surival Journal. Traveling around the map seems like a mess because I see all these monuments that I just discovered, but it's just very confusing and nothing is truly recognizable. Unlike in Castle Crashers where there were different and recognizable districts with different enemies. Here, the map is just a cluster of different biomes clashed together in no recognizable structure and generic monuments that I cant really tell apart.Also, what even does leveling up do to my character other than refill their health?Sorry if this review seems like a mess, I wrote it quickly. Other than these complaints though, I have no big problems. I have loved all of behemoth's previous games and they are amazing. I trust they'll improve this game and make it even better than it is right now in Early Access.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer:  I don't think this game is bad. I don't think this game is good. I think this game is OK and got too many positive reviews, which try to push nonsence that if devs made 2 good games all their games will be good. Also I felt like those reviews aren't helpful, so this is my attempt to write helpful review. Next, this is early access, and I think criticism will help devs to create better game. And finally dev said that he not promises to add new units. So here what I think:Good:+A lot of customization options+Music+Artstyle could be better, but I like it+Interesting recruiting mechanic, where you should kill everyone except your target and put him in cage.Bad:-You can't choose target for attacking. You just come in attack range and when turn ends your troops choose targets from those that they have in attack reach. In theory this is interesting, but in some places it just becomes annoying. For example on quest to kill Necroduke your troops will attack anyone except of Necroduke itself.-Next, it lacks tactic. Your troops can: attack, heal, summon allies and throw nets. I believe that's all. And you can't even chose target, you just move them and they act by themselves. -And to previous point, it lacks variety as whole. You can see all units in first 1-2 hours. It could be interesting pokemon-like game if it had more variety and dangerous monsters, but there like 18 monsters. And developer said that they won't promise to add new monsters.-And so it quickly becomes boring. Battles are mostly the same where you dance around trying to cover ranged units and healers.-I felt like battle result depends from party composition too much. And you can't see enemy party composition before actual battle.-It has difficulty settings, but no actual reward for playing on insane difficulty. I expected special hats, monsters or at least achievements. I get it, older games had no rewards for hard difficulty, but now I'm so spoiled that want rewards for playing harder difficulty than everyone.-No actual explanation what soldier stats mean, just some confusing graphs. Same for attack types and moves.-Level up just refills your HP. I haven't noticed anything else. So low level troops with fast levelling much better than useless veterans with long levelling.-Sometimes scenery blocks view, for example, again, castle of Necroduke has walls that won't let you see what happens in hexes behind them.Ugly:*Humour is not for everyone. I had a giggle in the beginning, but that's all. That's fine I guess, not everyone has same sence of humour.*Narrator is not that good. I found him not funny, just plain annoying. But again, this is subjective.Feel free to add your points in comments, but be constructive.

number of helpful: 44 of 136 people (32%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								The game so far is good.  I mean, really, so far the combat is fun. However...- This game's controls are ♥♥♥♥ing infuriating.  It was clearly made for consoles.  The responsiveness and way the mouse works in this game is just bonkers.- Related to controls: specifically, navigating the fighter inventory area is clumsy and cumbersome.- Related to controls: the whole game is built upon "Left Mouse Button selects,  RMB cancels".  It's just not user-friendly for PC.- The amount of feedback/information about stats, items, etc. is killing me.  The number of times I stared at the screen asking myself "what does this mean?" tells me that they did not get enough feedback on the useability/UX side. - During combat: the art style, colors, animations during the planning phase makes it really hard to see what you're doing.  I've made a number of mistakes moving my players around and stuff because the way they display the planning phase is confusing.  There needs to be more of a clear delineation between characters, and a better way to give you a "high-level" overview of the battle during this phase.- The size of everything is like 300% too big.  It was clearly made for a TV sitting 8 feet away from you rather than a monitor 2 feet away.TL;DR it feels like a bad port.  The way that everyting is presented to you on screen is clearly indicative of a console game and that really hurts the PC experience.

								This game is interesting. . .an I wish I could say that is a good thing. While this game is Early Access, it is not riddled with bugs that create huge problems. I believe it is more of a feature skinny Early Access, and the way the game is, the coding should not be difficult, and a below average dev woul be able to create it without gamebreaking bugs, so that is not a big shock. To me, the game is very boring, too slow, and doesnt bring anything new to the tactics based RPG. I actually think it takes away a lot of things that make for a good tactical RPG.  The equipment diversiity is made in a way that they are only for looks. Getting new weapons and whatnot, just change what they look like, but all swords do the same thing, and all bows and so forth. I hate this, and really think it detracts from the replayability of a game like this. Games like Final Fantasy Tactics did this genre so well, and other games go and create something similar, remove some things, and change some things and add some things, but devs seem to constantly change the WRONG things, and make for a worse playing experience than what would otherwise be here.ALL that being said, this game is NOT bad, and is actually something that could be worth playing, if it were priced right. This is $5 game, when completed. Right now it should be on sale for $3 or $4, and never be more than $5 when done. Unfortunately devs don't know how to price games, and think their game is worth more than it is. Selling 1000 copies at $15, is far worse than selling 10000 copies at $5, and everything about this game screams under $10 game. Dev really needs to look at other games on Steam, and really decide how much this game should be priced at. Don't support this project at this price point, I beleive you will be wasting your money, and won't be happy with your purchase.

number of helpful: 16 of 94 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
Early Access Review
								This is purely a review based on release.The game itself is extremely well put together. It's a Behemoth game, after all. The humor is on point, the artstyle is extremely pleasing, the pure amount of character and party customization is almost overwhelming, and the combat system (which I at first thought was as convoluted as the Undertale path minigame) turned out to be pretty well understood.Sadly, this is also an Early Access game. And while I should not be expecting THAT much from an Early Access game directly on release, I find myself doing so anyways.You will almost always be outnumbered, outdamaged, and outplayed in every scenario "3 skulls and above". Now in another RPG this would be fine. But due to just how much damage and random chance (not just crits but location of hits, location of AoEs, who gets healed, etc.) there is, it can be extraordinarily frustrating to set up a team around a point. As there is no permadeath in the game, this is simply a setback and puts you back at the city to do it again. But the fact that most encounters are very focused on luck can be frustrating when you start taking longer routes.The game is also extremely lacking right now in main content if you don't want to either A. Explore and complete all the mini-quests, B. Complete your customization collection, or C. Fight your friends in the PvP arena. Now I know that the non-story portion is almost the complete focus of the game, but the thing I like most about Behemoth games is that I can run through the story (acquiring collectibles along the way) and basically play through everything. I don't have any incentive to go out and collect customizations (because most customizations are exactly the same stat-wise, with a select few being either elemental or slightly more powerful). I don't have any incentive to go out and capture more recruits (because this is just used to get more customizations and all characters of a class have the same stats). And while I played the single story mission (which you can clear in about 10 minutes) and enjoyed it, I do wish the focus of the game was a bit more linear as the open-world nature of the game let the monotony set in once I realized the above.This should be a game I enjoy, as "turn-based hex-RPGs" are a favorite of mine (Civ, Fire Emblem, etc.). But the freeform nature of it makes it it hard to recommend right now as anything more than a collectathon. If a friend has is, by all means take a swing. It doesn't take long to get caught up to another person gear-wise, and it's enjoyable for the time I spent on it. But if you're looking for an extreme amount of substance ala Battleblock or Castle Crashers, you won't find that here (yet).

content:
Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								This developer would:-	Delete Their own posts from Community Discussion topics. (witnessed by me and others in The particular thread)-	Set Their profile to private state, when being accused on review injection (witnessed by me and,  supposedly the guy who actually accused Them)-	Flag your review for being abusive and then send you a friend-request. (I’m not really into ♥♥♥♥♥slaps)-	Allegedly, remove the flag, after you would create a separate topic at the Steam Community Discussion-	To put it yet again.-	And engage you in ~ 1 hour bullfight, when They’re trying to post their response in the comment section, but some miserable author of review would delete them outright (My Spirits of alcohol reminded me, that They had 3 other takes previously, containing “let’s talk privately” explicitly, and I totally agree with them), until either Steam moderator action took an effect or They grew bore of it. Nyaaaah. Me won.-	Would either change the flag tag, or instantly reflag your review upon lifting (it was “Off-topic”, which suddenly became “Abusive” yet again in more than a week locked review)-	To be [not] continuedAnd now, Me start.Minnasan, ogenki desu ka? Your supper-popular reviewer Yuu-sama is back on the line! Rejo-o.. ah, mind it.So, I took up on a good advice and actually tried out the game. There was a good opportunity, because I’d gifted it to a friend who actually wanted it. Soooo~. It’s King Bounty. With customizeable characters instead of just stacks. I mean, the big part of the game is King’s Bounty rewinded on a 1.5 game hours-length map (yet, it’s EA, I know) . Pretty casual in comparison. No, absolutely casual in comparison. Even with 90’s original. What Pokemon are you talking about? I’ve never played it. But, you know, you can capture monsters in the latest KB games, and some of them a predefined on generation to join you anyway. There is no “Gonna catch them all” spirit? I guess it is. So, Pit People is just a casual 9€ TBS, like Adventure Manager and others with a sketchy mechanics and things.What about the other, even bigger part? It’s hum-or. And first things first - bleeeh. I can’t start to talk about it without that premise. It’s really sends me back to the phrase that began everything for this review: “It’s a Behemoth’s game!”. Jokes are passable, generally. But there are pits (in Pit People, yes, *ba dum-tss*). The closest example is Forest scene of Castle Crashers. They didn’t got rid of those funny feces detonations. Meanwhile, the man who anticipated this game and actually enjoyed it for 1.5hrs of the 1st act said, that the only thing bad in this game, currently, is “the degenerative sense of humor”. And for this part, he is right. But I would suggest there is a reason behind it’s presence. By the way, we never finished CC because of that.Stage change. With the review being locked, my life turned grey. I’ve got no wife, no kids, no warm touch from anyone, but General Vochka himself. That being said, I jumped into another abyss of my useless existence. Aaahh, ok, it was their discord server. I found here two moderator guys joking around about how 2 unicorns could create a Mobius and feces, more of them, of course (strongly reminded me this South Park’s episode, that I did not intend to watch; like the whole title). When I was left alone with one of them, I’ve started to provoke him (I wasn’t picky in the means, why should I?). Silenced, re-entering, watch him playing for a time, They came, me ban. Yes, I was kicked at the end, got yet another invite from Them and one more, too, which I’ve decided to took up. The other side was really irritated, plainly rude, so I’ve got no choice but to report it. Properly, through the ticket. I am an adult and strong-willed male, but there could have been woman, kid, or an elderly person in my place. And yesterday I got a response. This person would be restricted in their ability to communicate with other people through the Steam for some time. And I got 6 downvotes on my long-drown reviews this very Friday. It seems they are downvoting every.So, yes, my point is that some part of the “older” community, grown on the best pieces of Behemoth humor is acting, to put it mildly, strange. But yet, they got a special treatment, like “Sure, I’ll go and ban that digger”. This very part of community is expecting for Daniel to act in some generally known way (related to this very sense of humor). For example, They would delete Their own posts, setting Their profile to “Private” only to anger those, who would dare to doubt them. Childish? It is. But look at the beginning and the list what They already did.No, the man this stupid couldn’t possibly create games. I suspect, he do understand he can’t effectively fight some guy with “?” on avatar. It’s like fighting a faceless mob. And I am positive on that he knows it. But still, people expecting him to act in this way. Those very people he attracted with his first games, filled with iconic for the Behemoth sense of humor. Of course, it’s just my vision. But if you saw at least a bit of this whole process: wouldn’t you think it seems weird, if 7\10 of most useful reviews are “Behemoth game, so is good”? Wouldn’t you think it’s weird when some of the negative reviews got very ‘special’ attention? I guess, there is a reason for that.Said, Dan is a businessman. It’s just his model of advertising the games. He got reliable community core, which could beat him some of the tips, like write some positive reviews, for example. No, not injections. He didn’t pay them for that.And here we are: this game is in Early Access. It got a single playable act. Apparently, you can participate in the development with your ideas, but I suppose, some of the ‘closer’ people’s opinions would get priority over yours. If you hope that jokes in future acts would be more of “straight sense”, your expectations is likely to be futile.What’s left of this game? PvP? It’s casual TBS, any competitive one would beat it. No direct control on units? Dominions, Legion series is better by no means. Instant turns? Oh, boy, you made me remember this one from 2001 - Laser Squad Nemesis.The only reason to grab it is Co-Op. I guess, it’s a good reason. If you are able to withstand the “o-ha-ha” part. Or if you want to see a Casual TBS in your hands . Or you’ve already watched complete series of South Park.I was meant to compare this community with the one Klei’s got, but I’ve decided it would be malicious to compare 2 indie games by their “feel” (actually, I’ve asked them on occasion when their Barbie House is going to get build).No hard feelings, Dan. I’m not a developer and I can’t possibly judge you on the way you’re advertising your game. I know you’re going to lock this review, I’m going to see your waiting Tail in the comments soon (he’s such a coward in a real-time chat), but that is my opinion about your game. I’m not aiming to win this, I just wanted to understand the cause, the matter of why did it even start. By the way, I though you were panicking first, so this accusations of the guy, who likely laughed his guts off from the whole situation, must had been true. It seems like a total misunderstanding. I should thank those minions for letting me know. From now on, I’m going to go easy on my reviews (anyway, they are about to get downvoted to the Mariana Trench soon).I have to remove the original review, it would be there http://imgur.com/a/tDDri

number of helpful: 26 of 131 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13
Early Access Review
								Early Access Watcher Public Service AnnouncementGame: Pit PeopleUpdate Version: January 13th EA ReleaseDisclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer.Gameplay Footage: WARNING! This includes spoilers for the available story missions.


YouTube™ Video: Pit People - Early Access Watcher - 

			Views: 207		

			Disclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer. Also, some of the tracks had to be removed to keep this ad free. Please not there is music in the menu portions.		

I understand this is Early Access and the final product is not representative of the current state, but this PSA covers the state of the game as it is now. There are some things that stand out in a good way, but the content provided in terms of story and complexity is not worth the cost of the game at this time. Thankfully, this game will get made regardless of what happens, so this warning is just for those on the fence or looking for a single player experience over the multiplayer experience. Visuals and music are going to be amazing for some, off putting to others. If you played Castle Crashers or Battleblock Theater (I didn't, though I do own them), then the style will look familiar in terms of the shading and design. There is a massive amount of character customization in terms of weapons, shields and helmets, but armour isn't a factor yet. Music ranges from blasting techno to mild synth that I surprisingly found enjoyable. Voice acting is left to a few announcers and the narrator with the rest being incoherent gibberish that requires the use of subtitles to understand. For the setting and the bizarre nature of the world, it fits perfectly and adds to the zany dialog. The story is incredibly short right now, consisting of a couple of introductory quests that took me about an hour and a half to finish. Once it is over, the Pit (1-2 vs AI, 2 vs 2 players matches) and a collection of side-quests are all that lengthen the gameplay. This is unfortunate, mostly due to the narrator's amazing performance that was indeed the highlight of the game. He eats up the scenery with his voice over accompanied by some beautiful cutscenes and dialog that did get a chuckle in the back of my mind. It left me wanting more, which is why I was surprised by how little there was to the story considering the price tag. Gameplay is mechanically sound, but lacks depth in terms of character management and improvement. All stats are contributed by the characters level with weapons and armor filling in the rest. Swords are good for smaller foes, longer swords hit harder, maces are required to deal decent damage against heavy helmet wearers and the ranged weapons can deal splash damage or direct damage. Shields also range from small to huge, allowing for more projectiles to be blocked as the size increases. Weapons can also have special perks that can root characters to a spot, freeze opponents or stun targets. Otherworldly creatures also exist, providing attacks that can chain lighting across multiple targets, create minions after being hit or float to provide avoidance of land based traps. These creatures are mainly acquired through the process of recruitment (kill all but the creature, capture the creature in a cage) and add some life to a combat system boiled down to moving to a space and letting the character attack. You only choose the movement, leaving the attack to be determined by the position and hoping your character hits the guy you want if they are standing next to two enemies. It has gotten to the point that I let the computer handle combat for me while I just maneuver across the world map in search of new locations and enemies during my last hour of play. The best way to describe it would be if you simply moved units and used auto-attacks. From what I was reading up, this game has been in development for awhile and has a standing deal over on Xbox One Game Preview as well. While I commend the developer for providing a functional core, the lack of a longer story and minimalistic combat style make battles tedious after awhile. The party system (can have up to six slots with some creatures taking up two or more) at least provides countless creature/character combinations that helps keep the multiplayer fresh for those who will focus on the 2 vs 2 battles. For anyone looking for a decent single player experience, however, might want to wait for the story to expand further. For now, not recommendation is the best I can give it when comparing the price to the available main story content. This has been a EAW PSA.

Early Access Review
								Never thought The Behemoth of all companies would pull an Early Access "GOTCHA!", but here we are.Sure, I saw the usual Early Access disclaimers, but I've been following this game for 3 years, I thought for sure I'd get 5-10 hours worth of my $15.NOPE. 3 Years of development has apparently allowed them to finally establish the fundamentals of Pit People, but the game has ZERO CONTENT. You've got your basic intro quest, and ONE STORY QUEST (combined these two things take less than a single hour). Aside from that, you've only got repeatable filler quests, and repeatable arena skirmishes.Don't get me wrong:-The dialogue and story is hilarious-The gameplay is excellent-The sound and visuals are The Behemoth at its absolute bestBut there's only a fart's worth of content so far. If you want to support the company (they WILL finish it eventually I'm sure, unlike other Early Access scams), go right ahead, but don't expect more than a tiny, tiny sneak peak at the game itself.

Posted: March 23
Early Access Review
								This is a review from playing a fair amount in Early Acces. Note that my experience is from update 2/3 era so if you are reading this at a later time it might not be matching what the game currently is.The Feel:This is a perfect game for people that like silly things. There is weird humor and references going on all over the place. The one story mission and the few side missions that are available for play at the moment are really fun. There is also enough going on the world map to keep you busy.Gameplay:As this is a sort of tactical positioning game mixed with random elements, it does pretty much what it says on the box. You set up your team of silly fighters, you place them where you want them to go and chaos happens. This is not a bad thing. Even when I am defeated I can sigh with a smile. Just the sheer amount of weaponised silly items (giant banana, crazy hats, throwing a gun at someone called "self defense") just makes me laugh every time i see a new item. At the time of writing there are about a 1000 items to collect in the game to customize your fighters with, and every time I run into a new pack of fighters with new hats/weapons I get excited. The fact that you can only take the last standing opponent with you makes it so you have to choose which of the shiny new things you want NOW :).Regarding the price:Worth every penny. You buy it once, and then you have hours worth of gameplay, especially when you consider there is a great amount of "gotta catch 'em all" involved.Regarding replayability:In update 3 they added some daily tasks to do co-op with a buddy. Also you get an "Emperor's order" to give you some extra items the moment you complete a specific task. As these orders are infinite its a fine extra reward for stuff you'd be doing anyway. I think the biggest thing going for this game is definitely the collection of custom appearances and items that you can acquire. Any cons?:Like I said, it's still under developtment. I didn't notice anything that would interrupt the gameplay experience in terms of bugs or so. That being said I'd like to see less daily tournament points awarded for people using the auto battler (that's right, you can even play your own fights as a spectator, while the computer dukes it out). At the moment I believe the ratio in the unfair challenge is that  you get half points if auto battler was used during a fight. Since I use auto-battler a couple of times during the day for a few fights and still finished high up, I think the rate should be lower so that people that actually fight their own battles can feel more achievement. But then again I think this will be less of an issue when the player pool increases.Final thoughts?A great game for its price, especially when you are a completionist. As there is plenty of auto-save going on, it can also be played in short spans for when you only have a little time to relax. Everyone should have a 15 min. pit people break at work!

Posted: March 17
Early Access Review
								For an early access game I'm loving it so far.The commentary from the announcer and the conversations between the pit people actually had me laughing, not just a huff of air though my nose but actually laughing.The gameplay is simple yet fun, but I do think the characters can be a little buffed up when you get them around high levels. I have a team that are all around level 60 but they are still doing the same damage and taking the same damage from enemies I fought at level 1. Aside from the free health from leveling up there needs to be a little bif more of a reward there.The map is nice and open, with the idea of constanly changing the area you're in makes it feel some what fresh each time. The enemy placement is nice and diverse and there are enemies where you'd expect them to be, like robots in the techno zones and monsters in the gloomy areas. A few things could be explained the how the turbo effects the enemies and also shooting the sparkly ground gives you plenty of coins. I have yet to figure out what pushing all the buttons around the world map does but I'm working on that.The sound track so far is catchy, that's the best way to describe it. A few more tunes would be nice if those songs were given to specific battles. Like say you're fighting mainly humans you'd play X song, then if you go over to the undead area there would be a chance to play a uniqe undead song out of the main soundtrack for the rest of the world. But that's a personal idea.Another thing I would like to see is a little more interaction with the speaker, like a in combat modifier so if you're doing well he suddenly feels like you should die, special units the narator summons spawns on the enemy's team, like wise if you're losing. Just something more than just a voice to spice things up.Over all I really enjoy this game for what it is, and considering I can play this with a friend makes it that much better.

Posted: March 12
Early Access Review
								A very entertaining game with a wide variety of units and items to play around with in an amusing setting.The fact that you get to pick where your pieces go, but not what they do does make some scenarios a little more of a hassle than necessary - such as those where you have to destroy an item but the character in question is adjacent to one or more enemies and decides to attack them instead of the scenario-advancing widget.There are also a few scenarios where additional enemies are rapidly  and repeatedly added to an already ugly situation that are a bit obnoxious, but perhaps those are intended for teams of very high level characters or co-op groups. I've only hit about three that give me that impression - and early access is probably a good enviroment for a company to work out how players manage the scenarious they have in mind.But those are relatively quibbly issues. Aside from the story missions, there are a great many other missions scattered around the landscape - and it's easy enough to try out team ideas on wandering monsters in the countryside. Early access games can be a bit of a risk, but Pit People seems like a very entertaining game even in its early access state.

Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								Like Pokemon, only more horrifying, and otherwise superior in every way.If you enjoyed the classic gameboy Pokemon games for any reason other than the connected TV series, you will love this. You've gotta catch all the fighters, level them up, and complete the story mode.It's superior because it's both simpler to learn and harder to master. Instead of choosing from a menu of options, you just decide where your fighters stand. Next turn, you can have them stand somewhere else. Then somewhere else. Then somewhere else. Then, depending on how good your choice of location for them, you'll either win or lose.The spatial aspect of it means you cannot memorise and execute a standard strategy like you can in Pokemon. Here, you must react to whatever situation you're put in, so even the exact same battle won't play exactly the same twice. This adds so much depth to the strategy, as you need a contingency for everything.However, it's much quicker to pick up, as your options are "stand here" or "stand somewhere else". You don't have to learn what a list of items or attack types do. Although a detailed working understanding of the game is a big help, it's not essential to gain the experience of actually playing it.My biggest gripe with the game (though Pokemon and most other games are equally guilty) is that it provides no detailed guide or wiki to help me fully understand what I'm looking at. What does it mean if a tile is on fire? What does it mean if my fighter is glowing purple? What does and does not count as a helmet? How is damage calculated? How big a buff is a singular level up?I wouldn't mind so much if the game were terrible, because I could just set everything to easy and play through for the story. However the game is so good that having to learn the details through trial and error is frustrating, because I genuinely want to learn the details.If there were a very detailed guide or wiki that gave enough information for a FULL understanding of the mechanics, I could see this as an e-sport, and I could also see myself spending more time reading that guide than actually playing. That said, as it is, I still enjoy perhaps one battle per day, though I still can't figure out what it means when fighters glow purple, and this annoys me.

Early Access Review
								This game ticks so many boxes:A "gotta catch-em-all"approach to party/team formation.Customisable characters.Online pvp.Brilliantly wacky single player/co-op story.However, your enjoyment of this game will hinge upon how much you like games focused on turn based combat. The combat is undeniably the core of the game. As easily accessible as it is, turn based games are not everyone's cup of tea. If you're already a fan of any kind of turn based game, you're sure to find pleasure here. If not, while there's still a lot to love, it may take some adjusting to.Pit People is a wonderful game all in all. The level of customisation and depth is outstanding considering how easy to access it is for a game of this type. The story content is lacking, but that's why the game isn't full price yet. There's more to come in coming months from a reputable studio. One of the safest 'Early Access' bets out there.

The sky is the limit for content updates and maybe a balance patch, but this is absolutely a game you want to be on the ground level for. Its only going to get better, and its already great.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								I'll write this review from the point of view of a dedicated RTS and RTT games. I reckon the items and strategic elements in this game are many, and that allows for a wide array of tactics depending in your taste and personal strategy. For instance, there are not just shields, swords, maces or damage per se. There are currently 3 times of shields which work differently from each other, and somewhat realistically enough (i.e. The massive pavise like ones provide no protection in melee but great coverage from ranged damage). There is also the concept of pierce damage and blunt damage, accuracy, and light and heavy armour with related maluses. Apart from unit customisation and the related strategy, there are also different races you can pick from. So far I have seen apart from humans: spider like humanoids called spidaurs, robots, vampires in a half human giant bat form (vampires), hair trolls, cyclops, mushrooms (yes lol), small jawa like lads that come in 2 for each slot*, fairies, cupcakes, wraiths and zombies. I guess I missed some, and several might be added later. *Slots are what determines how many fighters you can have in your team. You start with 4 open slots and can unlock 2 more easily enough early in the game. Not all races take the same amount of slots. Cyclops and trolls take 2 slots each, the jawa like gnomes take 1 but come in a couple. Of course that means the unit taking more or less slots is proportionately stronger or weaker. As a player of Total War, Heroes of Might and Magic, and Age of Empire titles I can't whine about what the game says it is offering. I'm actually very satisfied of the diversity that they put into the game. The humour is very likeable, and so is the story. A more detailed review will come as the game is fully released. Overall for its price I would rated it less than 10/10.

Early Access Review
								This game is great. I took a look at the negative reviews and the few there are complain that there is little story content. I just wanted to write a review to make it clear that that really doesn't matter in my opinion. Story is coming, this is an early access game. But for me where this game is likely going to shine is in the multiplayer. I could easily see myself dropping over 100 hours into the pvp system alone due to the amount of variety there can be. You have to go capture the monsters/get the weapons and that itself might be tedious as there aren't too many quests, but when you have stuff it looks like it's gonna be endless fun. Definitely up there for most amount of polish for an early access game.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Well, let's begin, shall we?So, to start off, the fact that it's a Behemoth game does bring multiple hopes and anticipations, no doubt. But it also ensures that this game, even in Early Access, has some bars to reach, or at least start showing the work it's wanting to make to get there. It's an interesting situation, with high potential, but high needs and desires.Which is why, after the first hour of the game, I can honestly tell you that the promise it shows is magnificent, and the game itself so far is quite enjoyable. Between the artstyle coming together quite well with this sort of genre and gameplay, giving the game a life and enjoyability that's present even when wandering the plains of the game, to the gameplay being simple enough to pick up after the initial tutorial, yet intricate enough to ensure it isn't a "Click to win" situation.Of course, it does have a few issues. In the beginning, there wasn't a large amount of explanation as to how certain gear works and what some of those stats change, or increase or decrease the chance thereof, and will little explanation as to the nature of whether or not weapons were simply reskins, or have their own stats. I found myself struggling through this sort of issue in the beginning, but had it settle out quite well when you find drops that do infact have stats of their own, albeit rather small and specific, but nonetheless. So while it DOES try to enlighten the player through the tips given while traversing, I found the character loadout designing to be a bit of a beast to understand at first, but as above stated, this is easily remedied with a bit of time in the game. Just a slight warning for anyone who may be turned off because of such.Ultimately, I'd recommend the game. While it is a bit lacking in content outside of the story (this being in Early Access, that should be obvious), I do feel that it brings enough entertainment and interest in it's state right now, even if you don't find an interest in the online/offline multiplayer. And with the Pit, the playability does infact come in greater and greater amounts.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								I've been incredibly hyped for this game to release since the trailer. Behemoth the developer does amazing work and their games are some of my favorites of all time. Customization is endless with over 1000 different items to collect to pimp out your team. Lots of different classes and diversity. Difficulty is meh, it seems to not be very hard so i reccomend actually going into insane mode ASAP. CO-OP is awesome so if you have friends GET THIS. The humor in this game is like all their other games, immature and hilarious. Anything from poop jokes to funny fraises this game is definitatly a great choice for younger and older audiances who love that kind of stuff. Voice acting is probably at its best in this game above all of their previous games, the narrator is just amazing. Campaign is pretty short for an early access game but it has plenty of incredibly fun and unique side-quests that all feel different. I've got about 10 hours on XB1 and 3 hours on PC. If you have a console i reccomend getting it on that, it's just simply better in my opinion. The PvP is good but can be annoying to find a game, that also is valid with CO-OP. I wish there was a gamechat so you could maybe talk to the person you're fighting with or against. With 15$ you'll get on average 15 hours-20 hours before it becomes kind of a numb loot grind if you're trying to get all the customizables. There is one aspect I have not treaded and that is the 3v1 unfair mode which seems fun. I tried it in the beta and boy did it kick my pooper until it was bruised and bloody, not much has changed since the beta besides more side-quests and better connection. For early access I would give it a solid 9/10 because the campaign's length, low difficulty setting, and lack of gamechat.I tried to be un-biased as possible in this review, so don't take anything with a grain of salt!

Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								Highly recommended, especially for fans of The Behemoth.At the time of this review the game is in early access and only contains about 1-2 hours of campaign, but there is much more to do after you've finished what's been released so far.Pit People is an easily accessible, turn-based, tactical/strategy game. In the campaign you start out with a small party of weird-o heroes who traverse an open world searching for quests, loot, revenge, and fighters. As you progress you are able to capture enemies and collect gear to add to your armory, giving you the chance to fine tune your party into a ruthless quad-killing machine.After completing what's available of the main story line you and your party are given free reign of the world. As you grab more fighters and gear you're encouraged to put them to the test in the pit where your party is pitted against "unfair AI" or other players online.The campaign and side quests are brimming with moxie. This whole game is just full of it, even the environment dances to the upbeat soundtrack.PROS:-Local and online CO-OP-Online multiplayer VS-Fantastic hex turn-based combat-AI brawling-Easy to access, difficult to master-HIlarious-RPG-ish elements that get the "ooo! numbers going up!" part of your brain tingling-Lots of stuff to collect-Lots of stuff to explore-Insane difficult mode-Ability to refuse space-bear's commands and not dieCONS:-It's in early access, but some minor UI issues.-At this point in time the campaign is very short, but you're getting it for cheap and there is so much more to do than the campaign.In conclusion:If you love Behemoth games and want to play it now, get it, it's worth it and in a completely playable state. If you don't like the idea of a short campaign maybe purchase it now at the lowered price and leave it in your backlog until the whole game is released.

Early Access Review
								Yes.I already loved the style, humor and battle gameplay of this game, but the "capture new recruits" mechanic of the game sealed the deal for me. The game can be played almost entirely with a regular mouse and this is a huge plus for me. You do have to tweak the controls a bit though and I would have prefered if the mouse 3 button could be used to end the turn by default (instead of just space) but this could still change of course if there is enough demand for it. It's still a little rough around the edges (eg. menu control feels a bit clunky to me with mouse) but this is to be expected for an early access title and is subject to change. Still, it already plays like a finished product and the fact that things will still improve is very, very promising.Overall I think Pit People is a really fun game with loads of more potential. I recommend it to anyone who isn't afraid of early access.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								For me personally this might be Behemoth's best game so far. Granted they've only had 4 games, Alien Hominid, Castle Crashers, Battleblock Theater, and now Pit People. The humor is like those games but at its best. The narrator brings so much to the game surprisingly. The art style is the typical Behemoth artstyle and looks great as usual. Now, this is Early Access as of this review and the main story is not complete. It'll take you only about an hour an a half, maybe 2, to complete. However it takes a lot of different gameplay mechanics from other games that greatly increase the game's life outside of the story. The combat is like Fire Emblem or Xcom (more like Fire Emblem) where it's turnbased strategy, a sort of rock-paper-scissors mechanic of maces good against helmets, etc. Similar to many classic JRPG's there is a world map to roam and explore, where you can encounter many different types of enemy parties. Like Darkest Dungeon and Xcom, there is a base and like Darkest Dungeon, you have a choice of different, random missions that you can buy provisions for before setting out on the mission. And lastly, like Pokemon, you can capture and collect enemies and use them in your party. Now, many of these mechanics are like those of some Rogue-likes however this is not a rogue-like. If a character dies, they go back to town instead of perma-death. Along the early access path it would be nice to see a hardcore mode with permadeath in it. So far it is a great game and fifteen bucks is more than worth it.

								Now, we all have that ONE game we all love to play, this is mine. I have loved this game since the beta, put around 30 hours into it. I would recommend this game for anyone who wants a game to play with one other person, even though there are more enemies to defeat. Personally my favorite character would have to be the mascot, they're really helpful during fights because they allow you to gain more damage, to receive more experience to help you level up so you don't die. Back when castle crashers was originally made, 2008, I played it on my playstation 3. Now I know what you're all gonna say, "you console pleb" "PC master race". Well this was back 9 years ago, and I only had my father's laptop, a Lenovo Thinkpad. Anyways, I have loved all of the Behemoth games they have released, and played most of them on ps3 and pc. One thing I noticed though while playing this game today, was that when I ran into an enemy on the map, I shot a rocket at him, I was about to enter battle phase, but it took me out. I don't know if this was intended or not, but it's really helpful for sticky situations.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								The first few minutes of this game says it all. Pit People is a hilarious game with great artwork, which is fun to play and does not take itself very seriously. It is very self aware while still delivering an, this far interesting story (I say this far since the Early Access does not contain much of the story, but the little it contains is great).The gameplay itself is great. It is a fun, casual strategy game. You do not have to be particularly skilled to enjoy it and play it, but you can still apply quite a bit of strategy into it if you are more competetive.The world map is fun and interesting, and it is great to see all the creative places that the developers have made on said map.You have loads of customisation for your characters which is also great. It is also worth to note that this is probably the first Behemoth game where playing with controller is not better than playing with mouse and keyboard. You can still play with controller if you prefer that, which is fantastic. It just means more options for the player.I am looking forward to see the finished product. However this game is definetly worth it buying already, even if it lacks story. It is fantastic and fun both gameplay wise and aestethically. Not only that, but Will Stamper shows once again that he is the best voice actor ever. I cannot get enough of his voice in this game.Get this game NOW!

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								Mild spoiler warning, but honestly there is not much to spoil.***The mechanics work perfectly, but for now, everything is... basic. Everything works, yes, but it's just the bones with basic strats and counters. There's nothing really special put in yet. You can feel the artwork's funk, that Behemoth style of doing things. Whoever's been working with this has put heart into it.The world is appealing, it calls for adventure. I could vision theories of what I'm about to face in this game. will there be random or conditionally spawning legendary/unique monsters, can I recruit them as well, will there be hunt quests for them, can I get fat loot out of some rare or secret quests, what will happen in the main storyline as it gets done and so forth. It's a vast land in there and I want to search it's nooks 'n crannies for every conceivable piece of equipment and lore I can find. Or, you know... that's just how it feels in the game's open world.Ah, the story... the story is left undone. There's literally one main story quest after you get to free exploring. Not only that, so far it took some odd turns before it's unprecedented end. It was a disappointment, to say the least. "Hey the main story ends here but you can still grind for exp... right?" There WERE big warning signs about it though, so it's not like it came as a surprise. It just surprised how little there was.I get the feel there was multiple ways to do this and none was clearly chosen, every road that could've been taken was as much fun and rewarding for the producer and the consumer so almost none was scrapped. It's still too open to say anything else. I can imagine though. I would very much like an endgame battle where I could slap the antagonist's space nipples with swords and maces. I would like to see the characters grow a bit, y'know a little backstory for them so they won't feel like they're just slapped in. I'd love to see some stuff even after the main story is finished, that's like giving diamonds to me. (or you can just give the 'mondz, man. Give 'em. Come on, gib. Gib!)Yes, much is to be done. I'm still recommending it, but don't get your hopes up. Buy it now if you feel like supporting Behemoth, but for those who don't care about that: it's not worth yet. At all.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								This game ticks so many boxes:A "gotta catch-em-all"approach to party/team formation.Customisable characters.Online pvp.Brilliantly wacky single player/co-op story.However, your enjoyment of this game will hinge upon how much you like games focused on turn based combat. The combat is undeniably the core of the game. As easily accessible as it is, turn based games are not everyone's cup of tea. If you're already a fan of any kind of turn based game, you're sure to find pleasure here. If not, while there's still a lot to love, it may take some adjusting to.Pit People is a wonderful game all in all. The level of customisation and depth is outstanding considering how easy to access it is for a game of this type. The story content is lacking, but that's why the game isn't full price yet. There's more to come in coming months from a reputable studio. One of the safest 'Early Access' bets out there.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								It already feels finished. No bugs, no crashes, online battle system/pvp, co-op, leveling, fun equipment, replay value, its all already there.They want to add more story and more content obviously, but the core game is fleshed out and extremely fun. The bizarre and often low-brow humor works out well for the environment and the especially good voice-over work of the main narrator.Overall, this game is already done for an EA title. The sky is the limit for content updates and maybe a balance patch, but this is absolutely a game you want to be on the ground level for. Its only going to get better, and its already great.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								Pit People is an amazing, sarcastic turned based strategy game from the creators of Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theater. Quirky characters, hilarious dialogue, and the game play itself will keep you entertained for hours on end. Plus, the amount of characters you can recruit in game and the countless ways you can style them through in game items is endless. The fights are challenging enough to ensure you are properly building teams to suit your play style, but easy enough where you aren't fleeing each match out of frustration or fear.Pit People is a must - and I am excited to see it come out of Early Access in the future!The only 'critiques' is that some of the abilities in game aren't always tutorialized (how to drop poop to find your way home, using the gun on the wagon, various other in game abilities that you just kind of 'learn' over time), and another concern with co-op. In co-op mode, it makes it difficult for both players to choose their actions at the same time as the map auto zooms or allows your mouse to zoom to other locations. This has resulted in my co-op buddies and I just taking turns, and once they confirm their strategy then I make my moves and end the turn. There should be the ability to zoom out the map entirely.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								So, its a bit like heroes of might and magic meets pokemon but a little simplified.You start with your small band of fighters, and over time you can capture just about any enemy you fight. You can build your squad and mix and match to your hearts desire... this is where the game really shines.It also offers co-op which to my knowledge is a unique feature in any tactical turn based game... and one that I would love to see other games adopt/emulate. Overall, its a very good game for the price and id recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy games.The cons for me were, its a little too simple... the game does advertise that its a strategical position game... and that pretty much sums it up. And then also, the interface feels clunky in that it is obviously geared towards controller use.I want to use my mouse, and i'd like there to be the option to make it feel more natural when doing so.That all being said, its still a great game and I'll probably hit the hundred hour mark.

								Good things to say about this game:Hilarious narration.Not too hard to get into.Gameplay is relatively simple and easy to master.You can make some ridiculous teams.Cheaper to get it now than on full release (barring Steam sales).Tons of quests to find and do that have their own unique dialogue.Doesn't require hours and hours of grinding to be relatively decent in multiplayer.Adorable Kobolds (Most important thing on the list).Bad things to say about this game:The number of Story Missions are highly lacking as of the time of this post, (On the bright side, more stuff will be coming as the game develops more)It will suck up all your free time because of how fun it is.

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								For me personally this might be Behemoth's best game so far. Granted they've only had 4 games, Alien Hominid, Castle Crashers, Battleblock Theater, and now Pit People. The humor is like those games but at its best. The narrator brings so much to the game surprisingly. The art style is the typical Behemoth artstyle and looks great as usual. Now, this is Early Access as of this review and the main story is not complete. It'll take you only about an hour an a half, maybe 2, to complete. However it takes a lot of different gameplay mechanics from other games that greatly increase the game's life outside of the story. The combat is like Fire Emblem or Xcom (more like Fire Emblem) where it's turnbased strategy, a sort of rock-paper-scissors mechanic of maces good against helmets, etc. Similar to many classic JRPG's there is a world map to roam and explore, where you can encounter many different types of enemy parties. Like Darkest Dungeon and Xcom, there is a base and like Darkest Dungeon, you have a choice of different, random missions that you can buy provisions for before setting out on the mission. And lastly, like Pokemon, you can capture and collect enemies and use them in your party. Now, many of these mechanics are like those of some Rogue-likes however this is not a rogue-like. If a character dies, they go back to town instead of perma-death. Along the early access path it would be nice to see a hardcore mode with permadeath in it. So far it is a great game and fifteen bucks is more than worth it.

Posted: February 23
Early Access Review
								PRO: The first 10 hours are GREAT. I loved it.Lots of fun. Unique writing, entertaining, fun to learn the mechanics. CONS: After the first 10 hours, things start to feel repetitive and grindy.You are battling for rep and to unlock cosmetic changes to your characters.Every once in awhile you might unlock something that makes your character stronger.OBSERVATIONS: The cosmetic content unlocks, purchasing quests, and posting REP for all to see feel like necessary add-ons to keep people returning to the game once the original content and new discovery feeling wears off. I haven't tried out the multiplayer, but its not a draw for me. Although I love the game , Behemoth, and I'm happy to support them with my purchase, my 9 year old who LOVES all of the other Behemoth games doesn't even want to try the game out. I fear they missed the biggest consumer age group that drives their sales with this game. Here's hoping they are working on Castle Crashers 2 or Battle Block Theater 2 because this title might cause a huge problem for the studio if they don't come up with some way to draw in the younger players.I don't feel drawn to play the game repeatedly like I was with Castle Crashers or Battle Block Theater. Most of the replay value of those games were the easter eggs, leveling, and my son pushing me to play with him. The fact that he doesn't want to play this game at all means it won't get much use, which bothers me because I REALLY want this studio to succeed.

								This game is fantastic. It's amazing, totally great. The first thing you'll witness as you start the game is the amazing music it caress your moist ears with, after that you'll be thrown into a world built on the core of top notch humour. Well, The Behemoth delivered a fantastic CO-OP, PvP, online game once again!

								Looking at Pit People I didnt think i would enjoy it because turn based strategy is just not my thing, but i love everything behemoth has put out in the past, so I decided to try out the early access version because why not. I can easily say that even in its early stages is one of my new favourite games, once again I am swept away into a funny beautifully designed world that I cannot wait to keep exploring. The customization keeps repeditiveness to a low, the different classes of charecters makes for an interesting way to keep no battle the same, the weapons are simply done perfectly to where they are funny and not overpowered at all from what I have come to find, the loot system works extremly well (fight or do a quest get loot go to the main hub and you collect it), it is easy to pick up for people new to above turnbased, and its downright funny. The voice acting is a 10/10 along with the quirky music thats catchy, weird, and brings the atmosphere of this game together. I can tell I am going to be putting a lot of hours into the game. 10/10 behemoth, you done did it again

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Well, let's begin, shall we?So, to start off, the fact that it's a Behemoth game does bring multiple hopes and anticipations, no doubt. But it also ensures that this game, even in Early Access, has some bars to reach, or at least start showing the work it's wanting to make to get there. It's an interesting situation, with high potential, but high needs and desires.Which is why, after the first hour of the game, I can honestly tell you that the promise it shows is magnificent, and the game itself so far is quite enjoyable. Between the artstyle coming together quite well with this sort of genre and gameplay, giving the game a life and enjoyability that's present even when wandering the plains of the game, to the gameplay being simple enough to pick up after the initial tutorial, yet intricate enough to ensure it isn't a "Click to win" situation.Of course, it does have a few issues. In the beginning, there wasn't a large amount of explanation as to how certain gear works and what some of those stats change, or increase or decrease the chance thereof, and will little explanation as to the nature of whether or not weapons were simply reskins, or have their own stats. I found myself struggling through this sort of issue in the beginning, but had it settle out quite well when you find drops that do infact have stats of their own, albeit rather small and specific, but nonetheless. So while it DOES try to enlighten the player through the tips given while traversing, I found the character loadout designing to be a bit of a beast to understand at first, but as above stated, this is easily remedied with a bit of time in the game. Just a slight warning for anyone who may be turned off because of such.Ultimately, I'd recommend the game. While it is a bit lacking in content outside of the story (this being in Early Access, that should be obvious), I do feel that it brings enough entertainment and interest in it's state right now, even if you don't find an interest in the online/offline multiplayer. And with the Pit, the playability does infact come in greater and greater amounts.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								I've been incredibly hyped for this game to release since the trailer. Behemoth the developer does amazing work and their games are some of my favorites of all time. Customization is endless with over 1000 different items to collect to pimp out your team. Lots of different classes and diversity. Difficulty is meh, it seems to not be very hard so i reccomend actually going into insane mode ASAP. CO-OP is awesome so if you have friends GET THIS. The humor in this game is like all their other games, immature and hilarious. Anything from poop jokes to funny fraises this game is definitatly a great choice for younger and older audiances who love that kind of stuff. Voice acting is probably at its best in this game above all of their previous games, the narrator is just amazing. Campaign is pretty short for an early access game but it has plenty of incredibly fun and unique side-quests that all feel different. I've got about 10 hours on XB1 and 3 hours on PC. If you have a console i reccomend getting it on that, it's just simply better in my opinion. The PvP is good but can be annoying to find a game, that also is valid with CO-OP. I wish there was a gamechat so you could maybe talk to the person you're fighting with or against. With 15$ you'll get on average 15 hours-20 hours before it becomes kind of a numb loot grind if you're trying to get all the customizables. There is one aspect I have not treaded and that is the 3v1 unfair mode which seems fun. I tried it in the beta and boy did it kick my pooper until it was bruised and bloody, not much has changed since the beta besides more side-quests and better connection. For early access I would give it a solid 9/10 because the campaign's length, low difficulty setting, and lack of gamechat.I tried to be un-biased as possible in this review, so don't take anything with a grain of salt!

Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								I'll write this review from the point of view of a dedicated RTS and RTT games. I reckon the items and strategic elements in this game are many, and that allows for a wide array of tactics depending in your taste and personal strategy. For instance, there are not just shields, swords, maces or damage per se. There are currently 3 times of shields which work differently from each other, and somewhat realistically enough (i.e. The massive pavise like ones provide no protection in melee but great coverage from ranged damage). There is also the concept of pierce damage and blunt damage, accuracy, and light and heavy armour with related maluses. Apart from unit customisation and the related strategy, there are also different races you can pick from. So far I have seen apart from humans: spider like humanoids called spidaurs, robots, vampires in a half human giant bat form (vampires), hair trolls, cyclops, mushrooms (yes lol), small jawa like lads that come in 2 for each slot*, fairies, cupcakes, wraiths and zombies. I guess I missed some, and several might be added later. *Slots are what determines how many fighters you can have in your team. You start with 4 open slots and can unlock 2 more easily enough early in the game. Not all races take the same amount of slots. Cyclops and trolls take 2 slots each, the jawa like gnomes take 1 but come in a couple. Of course that means the unit taking more or less slots is proportionately stronger or weaker. As a player of Total War, Heroes of Might and Magic, and Age of Empire titles I can't whine about what the game says it is offering. I'm actually very satisfied of the diversity that they put into the game. The humour is very likeable, and so is the story. A more detailed review will come as the game is fully released. Overall for its price I would rated it less than 10/10.

								Been loving the game so much so far. I love the game. Some things that I think would make the gamplay better are:- Add some upgrades for your caravan (Permanent speed upgrade, faster reload, a spray that attracts and repels monsters, larger caravan to be able to store more items)- Need more late game items or things that you can buy (Call in the bear to bring you home, xp booster)- I would also love to see a monster tracker, something to locate certain monsters- I love the way when you collect coins the sound goes higher, but it would be cool if there was a bonus for getting a bunch of coins in a row. Maybe double coins for 30 secs or something like that- Customizable tournament against AI and alone- A quest to find a bunch of pieces, and it ends up creating a portal that brings you to a 1 time dimension ( doesn't have to be 1 time use, maybe you need to charge it everytime) and has lots of monsters and/or loot, but has very difficult monsters- Random events that can go on in your world (Monster Frenzy, Monster Horde, Gold Rush, Raining Somthing)- Random traps that you can fall in and bring you to a cavern with lots of monsters- Random healing/reviving fountains around the map- A way to explore the map and reveal locations and then create a mapI know this game is in Early Access, but it has a lot of potential and I love how it is going so far. I've made it to the top 10 in the tournament (I know I'll lose it soon). I wasn't sure where to add this so I just made it a review. If you guys are taking recommendations, sorry for posting this. Hope you guys read this and maybe add some things!Thanks for spending 5 minutes of your day reading this and hope you have a good rest of your day!

Posted: January 28
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								So a friend of mine wanted to play a game together with me, and having exhausted many options already he caught sight of Pit People while Strippin was playing it.  Excited he picked it up and chucked me a free copy, and then we tackled the game at the same time.To put it simply as the game stands now I definitely recommend it.  When it's a finished product I can only expect it to be significantly more fulfilling than the current rendition, which is already a good time to be had.  Now for a bit more detail...First and foremost this game is in Early Access and as of this review it has very little story missions to progress through.  There are plentiful sidequests on the maps, and a few side missions attached to the Quest Board in town, but Story Missions?  Almost none.  So if you're looking for the full game...wait a bit?Technically speaking this game is solid.  I've had zero crashes and almost no glitches to speak of.  I'm currently running Update 1(Beta) and that hasn't even generated any instability.  All in all a good bunch of programming.That isn't to say that the game is without bugs.  I've seen a few others complain about some that have popped up here and there. However...Behemoth seems to actually pay attention to the players.  I've seen an actual attempt by the staff to try and help those who are having problems with the game.  That's quite refreshing compared to what feels like cold, mechanical assistance from most bigger named and bigger budgeted companies.So the game is pretty good overall in terms of stability.  But how is it as a GAME?It's a turn-based strategy game with a plethora of various units and equipments for said units.  Each type of unit you can use has a weakness you can exploit, but you won't always face off against what you might want to which means you need flexibility in your loadout and playstyle.In terms of actual difficulty you'll find it to be sitting close to that sweet spot.  You can beat the opponents but they can get quite hard to handle if you're not paying attention.  My favorite thing, however, is that even if you're against something that is designed to beat you you won't automatically lose.  This isn't Rock/Paper/Scissors, and so weaknesses don't cripple you so much as merely hurt you.If you like turn-based stategy games you'll probably get a kick out of this.  If you hate them because they're too slow Pit People has a slightly faster pace than you might expect, so maybe check a video of a fight from the game.  If you simply hate strategy games even then this game might interest you due to the humor and art style.Also, yes, the music is awesome.

Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								So, its a bit like heroes of might and magic meets pokemon but a little simplified.You start with your small band of fighters, and over time you can capture just about any enemy you fight. You can build your squad and mix and match to your hearts desire... this is where the game really shines.It also offers co-op which to my knowledge is a unique feature in any tactical turn based game... and one that I would love to see other games adopt/emulate. Overall, its a very good game for the price and id recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy games.The cons for me were, its a little too simple... the game does advertise that its a strategical position game... and that pretty much sums it up. And then also, the interface feels clunky in that it is obviously geared towards controller use.I want to use my mouse, and i'd like there to be the option to make it feel more natural when doing so.That all being said, its still a great game and I'll probably hit the hundred hour mark.

Early Access Review
								I wasn't sure what to expect, I'm a huge fan of Castle Crashers & Battleblock Theater, but I'm not a fan of turn based games. This however, is a different story, I love this game, even in early access, it feels EXTRMELEY polished and is a joy to play, both solo and with a friend.There's tons of hilarious items to use, tons of Behemoth humor that I love, and tons of detail to the maps/arenas. As for the gameplay, it feels arcade-y, without losing a smidge of any strategic elements, which is very hard to do. Then there's the 'hub' where they have an Arena, Online, Item Shop, Character/Group Customization, which of course, is dislayed in a humerous style (I wont spoil). The map roaming is perfect for this game, lots of content, lots of things to fight, plenty of quests and side quests to do, none of which are filler. Props to The Behemoth for creating another awesome, masterfully crafted game that I need to recommend!

								I'm excited to see the limited amount of content grow. Behemoth has always done a great job putting together unique games with their own sense of humor and style. As of early access, they still deliever with their signature style. The art of Dan Paladin is ever present. Simple, humorous, delightful. The fighting system is simple but shallow and there's two story missions along with a few side quests. I imagine over the next year (in which Behemoth works towards release) mechanics and story will be built upon. So if you're buying it now, know you're only going to get a few hours of enjoyment at first. But if you believe the track record of the Behemoth team and their wonderfully unique spirit, it's worth to get the game now and support the team!
